reviewText:
Find a copper vein. Mine it.
Find a tin vein. Mine it.
Start digging deeper.
Find an iron vein. Mine it.
Realize being a gopher is a foolish task. Set up conveyer belts.
Realize you're still being a damn gopher. Set up laser energy transfers.
Realize its about 3am, or whatever your equivilant of way-past-bedtime is. Continue digging deeper.

Edit below:

Notice these annoying bugs attacking your Power Hub. Shoot them.
Realize that your pea-shooter sucks, and so does the spiderbots. Build Turrets.
Why aren't these missiles shooting anything? Aren't those Heavies large enough targets?
Build the Orbital Energy Transfer contraption. Gawk at its size and requirements.
OH GOD THOSE THINGS ARE HUGE! Oh hey the missiles are shooting at it.
Keep digging deeper.

Greetings dear reader, and thanks for taking the time to read my input.  Before I proceed, I have a suggestion; Do the following:

Step 1.) On the Store page for this game, where it tells you whether the reviews are Positive, Mixed, or Negative, click on that (It says mixed for me right now, but there's no telling what it says for you).

Step 2.) You should see a Heading that says Helpful customer reviews".  Observe the filter.  I suggest you click on "Negative".

Step 3.) Read a few of the negative reviews.  I read about 6 of them and noticed a trend.  See if you notice something as well.

Step 4.)  Now
date: keeping everything you've read in mind
recommended:
go back to the main store page and scroll down until you find the link on the right that says "View Update History".  Compare the content of all those negative comments with what you see now on the update history.

Now we may proceed.

Did you notice a pattern?  A trend?  My observation was that it appears that the bulk of the negative comments on this game consist of individuals who do not comprehend the meaning of "Early Access".  I say this because

reviewText:
How best to describe this game.  Take the technic mod from Minecraft and make it 100 times better.

This is one of those games that are pretty simple to figure out, but as you progress it gets a bit more complicated.  Mainly this game is all about logistics.  Getting resources transported from your mine to your base so you can smelt it and make new items and do research.  All while defending your base from aliens that attack you if your base threat gets over 100%.  If you like a game about logistics you will love this game.  At first it starts off very slow and you manually do everything, but as you progress you start to automate.  It is when you get to the point where you start automating everything where it can either be a whole ton of fun or a logistics nightmare.  You have to make sure you have enough ore coming in to feed your smelters.  So you are always looking for new veins of ore to tap and send up to your base to be smelted.  Plus having to figure out how to get power down to your mine and also keeping a nice design of your base.

One thing to remember is you can just about move anything except for the CPH and the research station.  So don't be afraid if you build your base one way and want to change it later.  I have done so many redesigns to my bases because I didn't play far enough ahead and had to tear most of it down and rebuild it.

I am not going to do a Pro's and Con's list.  Because it is still in early access and things change almost on a daily basis.  Also remember that this game is early access and things do change.

Overall it is a very enjoyable game and I have put in tons of hours into it and I am looking forward to new things as they get added so I can implement them into my base design.

I do recommend you run the Bleeding Edge beta if you are planning to play it because it has all the newest stuff in it.

Also the Dev is really awesome and have talked with him several times and he loves input about the game.  I stream this game and he has watched my stream several times and has even helped me out a few times because I didn't have things setup properly and he walked me through it.  He talks with others in chat in the stream and answers questions people have.  This is the first time I have actually seen a dev actually watch a stream of their own game and ask for feed back from those watching and from the person streaming.

My overall opinion of this game is grab it.  It is ton of fun and you can also play with friends (just gotta open up a port on your router).  One of the few games out there that is truely Co-op.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy this game was a bit of a turd when i got my hands on it last week i believe. It was rough, a lot of things didn't function properly and I was confused as hell. Went to the forums and almost 1:1 the dev was posting back and talking, on all the forums I checked. Big ups for that.
What about the game? Well its minecraft style construction and world building but that's where the comparison ends. You extract ores to creat ingots to create new machines to support your lazy butt because the name of this game is automation. There's been more than once where I just sat back and let my machines work to produce some ingots i needed or research modules. This game has some serious depth to it and with all my hours I have in the game, they're all in ONE SAVE. Last game I played that let me do that was Dark Souls. So Yeah this game deserves your attention. It doesn't look the best but the gameplay is fulfilling and there's tons to work towards. SOme crack head said one of the end game items was a 20 hour work, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t 50 hours in and i ain't got it. I just finished the last of the tech tree so now I get to build the fancy ♥♥♥♥ i researched. So pick this up because its worth your money and if you're having issues ask the dev because i've had full conversations with the guy. He's really cool and helpful. He takes your complaints and suggestions into considerations.
They fixed more bugs than i can count when I started this game. I love it.

reviewText: Well after only 900 hours into this game I think its time to write a review. This game SUCKS my time. I can't stop playing it. Every time there is a couple of new updates (at least once a week) I start a new world to see the new stuff. I have yet to finish it. Something new will come along and some of the stuff on the old world just isn't as good, so start again. Every time I get a little bit faster and a little bit further along but I just like to try to build all the items and see how they work. I only wish that you could download all of the different versions to really see how far this game has come. The developers are on the forms constantly updating. The only problems I have ever had with the game is trying to run an old version after a major patch and then some items mess up. So what, start again and see all the new stuff. My favorite part is that I don't have to finish the game to play it. It's not linear. Do what you want. Have fun, mess up, start again.

reviewText:
With over 2,000 hours playtime  you can believe me when I say, YOU WILL LOSE TIME PLAYING THIS GAME.
If you enjoy resource management under pressure then you will love this game. If you are creative and love building with blocks then you will love this game.
The Devs are passionate and update the game very regularly and follow bug reports closely on the forums just make sure reports go in the correct threads or they may be missed.
The Survival part of the game has a good Tutorial to start you off but be prepared to use your brain to work out advanced systems to build a huge mining operation on a hostile world.
The Creative side of the game gives you unlimited resources to build almost anything you can imagine, with the ability to create detail blocks to give even more finesse to your work.
You get one huge and addictive game for your money, so go for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

review of 1.9 EA

OK, it has blocks, crafting, and mining. That's where the similarities end really.

My daughter plays Minecraft, she plays it for hours. However, whenever I sit down to have a go, I get bored after about 20 minutes. You dig. You build. You dig. zzzz

FortressCraft is much more immediate than that. Your power is running out, you're going to freeze to death, so you need to organise. This forces you to think stategically, about power, about distance, about supply lines (and presumably, in the future, defending them from other players). It kind-of feels more like a RTS, but with blocks.

If you're used to other Mine games, this one IS even more complicated. But part of that is due to a very alpha GUI, things aren't as obvious as they could or should be. This will be fixed!

for example, bringing up your inventory, you have a bunch of blocks. What are they? no idea, a mouse-over tooltip would be nice :)

Also, I'd rather you only had things in  your toolbar that you actually owned, it's too confusing with *every possible thing* being shown, yet you can't use 90% of it. Again, early access, these things are to be expected.

One thing that is immediately wrong" with the game - shelter. If you build a "house" over your base equipment
date: put a torchfire or two in there
recommended: surely it should be warm enough inside that you don't freeze? What's the point of building a "Fortress" if it doesn't have any benefits lol :)\n\nI absolutely recommend this

reviewText:
I bought this game in early access because I thought it showed promise even though it was a clear Minecraft and Factorio clone and the developer has had very public arguments with the creators of Minecraft over the issue, I was wrong. Since then it has degenerated into the mess that it has become today, an unfinished hodgepodge of ideas found in other games with no clear direction, no character and no fun. The mob graphics are shoddy and the loot system is incredibly weak. Players consistantly complain that they find progression to be awkward and the game has no real aim or endgame amongst other flaws in basic game design which prevent them from working through the messy research system but the one-man-band developer refuses to accept their concerns, maintaining that his design is flawless, and original of course, so they walk away having wasted their hard earned cash on a bad clone. This game should never have left early access at it stands and shouldn't really even be on Steam.

I asked one of the devs why there were no building blocks available in the survival part of the game and they told me... and I quote from Skype...  I can't be bothered to write the recipes"  I later find that they're selling the survival game blocks into the game one by one to Patreon supporters as though they're a commodity.  I've never heard of anything so stupid.  A voxel block game with no voxel blocks until Patreons 'buy' them for the playerbase?  What a joke.

If you're considering purchasing this game you should know that even though the base game is unfinished
date: the developer is now concentrating on a paid expansion pack which he intends to sell for $8 (subject to Valve approval). If you buy this game now you will not be able to use the resources you see ingame unless you pay an extra 8 bucks for the expansion. No

This game is voted more negative has it should be. It's quite interesting and plays like a big Minecraft mod but without the normal Minecraft features. It has many flaws, some easy ones like lack of help at the beginning and some bigger issues.
Things that could be better:
- needs cables. Using batteries as a replacement for cables for small distances is expensive at the beginning and also quite inefficient. The laser energy transmitter are bad for diagonal stuff. There should be cables for medium distances.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has quite a few negative reviews and i have to say not all points are justified.

I really enjoy this game (i only play on survival) and it's a verry good spin on the many voxel block games out there first off it's not focused on being creative as in making big castles etc ( i guess you could but there are other games that are better at this) Where this game shines is in optimizing your base you're building a huge factory/mining operation and everything needs to be powered by different means which makes it a little of a puzzle game in my opinion.

people have commented on the fact that the tier 1 takes too long and it's too hard to get to tier 2. I have to say i love starting over and beginning from scratch I actually do so after every bigger update (even though it's usually not even necessary).

other people have commented that the development is too slow or non existent and although it may seem like this the last few months if those same people would follow the twitter they would see what the devs are really working on and at this point that is mobs and battle this is not a small task so the smaller quick updates may be gone for a while untill this is done.

I'm not saying this game is perfect yet (far from it ) but isn't that what the early acces warning is for.
Too many people ragg on the early acces games giving negative reviews for things that are bugged etc that comes with the territory. People pay money for something and expect it to be a fully functioning completed product even though there is a big blue warning saying EARLY ACCES. Guess what i just bought a house thats not even finished building yet and i'm not at the construction site with a big  sign saying this company sucks my house doesn't have a roof and the toilet doesn't flush etc. same thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Watch out! This is an actual review with actual details about the game and such. you may not want to read this. I know most people like to read / write reviews that only gives 1-2 vague sentences about the game.

I’ve been playing FortressCraft for 4 years now. I originally bought FortressCraft on the Xbox when it first came out back in April of 2011. I have played the Xbox hundreds of hours and have been there through all of its development. I can sit here all day and tell you all about the Xbox version too, but this isn’t about that version, this is about the evolved FortressCraft, FortressCraft Evolved.

FortressCraft Evolved isn’t a port or a remake of the original FortressCraft, it’s a reimagining. The game has been completely rewritten from the ground up using Unity as the game engine (They were using XNA framework on the Xbox).

This review is of version 1.15d. I’ve owned FortressCraft Evolved on Steam since the beta for the pre-alpha (You had to know someone to be able to play it, wasn’t available for purchase on Steam yet; It was hidden).

Story:
There isn’t one currently, unless you count the 2 paragraphs of text in the help menu.

Main Menu:
Currently, the main options in the main menu are the 'join multiplayer server option and the world select option. You can create and select at least 10 worlds currently. You may be able to make even more than that
date: but I have never had need for more than 4 worlds at a time because the creative worlds are so large
recommended:
I can just go find another place and start building.

Graphics:
The graphics are great. There are shadows and mist
hoursPlayed: and dynamic colored lighting. The textures are HD and the models are very good.\n\nYou can change the resolution of the game
voteText: whether it is full screen or not
helpfulPercent:
and the quality of the graphics.

Controls:
I read a lot of reviews that say the controls are horrible and this and that and I don’t know about them
votesHelpful: but I don’t have any troubles at all. You move with wasd and any command you need to press ‘on-the-fly’ are all within reach of your left hand. Keys that aren’t are things such as: The Help Menu (h)
votesTotal: Toggling the headlight (L) (which requires power and glow sticks are better (g key))
votesFunny: Inventory (i)
commentsCount: and that is it.\n\nAs for creative
column16: you will have to use the F9-F12 keys to use the special build commands
column17: such as super build and copy / paste.\n\nAny complaints about the buttons being in a bad place are really rather dumb though as you can customize any button. When you first launch the game
column18:
a configurator appears and you can scroll through every ‘control’ and change the key and also change / set a secondary key. Don’t like the “Toss a glow stick” key being G? Change it.

You can also change the sensibility of the mouse in both the X and Y position and you can invert it.

Playability:
The game does have a few bugs and mishaps
column19: but as far as playable
column20: it is very. I can get on survival mode and play for 5 hours straight and have almost no issues. Almost all bugs are found pretty quickly and are reported to the developers who are actually pretty active. For an Early Access game
column21: I would say it is high on playability. Is it perfect? No

but it's...EA...

Annoyances:
You can not change worlds without exiting the game. This will be changed before it leaves EA though.

You can not change the graphics and controls in-game
column23:
only in the startup menu. This does not include sensitivity.

Creative mode:
This first mode is creative mode. This mode has transformed a lot over the years and I think the best thing about creative mode are the custom blocks.

Custom blocks allow you to create...custom blocks. You create what is called a ‘workshop’

column28: and 8x8. You can place blocks inside the workshop

Check out the 13th picture in the Steam picture roll for the store page to kinda see more about what I’m talking about (The train).\n\nThe other special feature about creative (and is in survival) is called build-to-me. You hold down control and click on a block out in the distance

reviewText: Our Darker Purpose" is a "me too" roguelike that no doubt means to sail in the wake of runaway successes like The Binding of Isaac. Unlike the others
recommended: ODP offers significantly more in the way of RPG elements.\n\nIn terms of gameplay
hoursPlayed: ODP is very much in the real-time roguelike tradition
voteText: with a series of rooms in which the player faces challenges of combat or dexterity. You are locked in a room until you complete it
helpfulPercent:
and then may enter an adjoining one.

Pros
Compared to other roguelikes
votesHelpful: ODP has level progression per session
votesTotal: with choices of perks at each level-up. Your choices are effectively a build for the session
votesFunny: and reduce the randomness normally associated with roguelikes.\n\nThe gothic art style is a good choice
commentsCount: and was no doubt influenced by Edward Gorey
column16: a personal favorite of mine
column17: as well as more recent expressions of the genre
column18: such as "Don't Starve."\n\nODP has a story that unfolds in fragments
column19: and while it's hardly a masterpiece
column20:
it's far more than one would expect for the genre.

Cons
The lack of controller support is a big mark against the game
column21: and an oversight that is more egregious considering the genre.\n\nI like the sketchy
column23: but ODP's art style feels amateur and inconsistent. Some objects feature sharp
column24: fine lines and hard edges
column25: while others are soft and look like they've been heavily resampled. Also
column26: there is insufficient variation in room props. I've seen many pixel-perfect-identical desks or chairs spawn in neat grids in the room.\n\nThe pacing is poorly managed
column27: and the rooms quickly become boring and repetitive. Many rooms require far more patience than actual skill
column28: at times making the game a tedious slog.\n\nPickups are mostly uninteresting and give small bonuses to stats like health
column30: and damage. Roguelikes usually feature a variety of highly powerful objects or abilities
column32: very interesting ones with multiplicative synergy. ODP's pickups lack synergy and (generally ) only linearly affect stats.\n\nThe game's difficulty is disappointing. The game is very easy when compared to hardcore roguelikes
column33: and will probably disappoint players who expect a serious challenge."

reviewText:
Think....Minecraft meets Turret defense.

The game is pretty solid in the minecraft department. It has all the fun and creativity of minecraft, but takes a lot of the tedious repetitive things out. There is also a research system, which works pretty well.

I've focused most of my time into building my base, making my mining operations efficient, going deeper underground, and where I'm at, I find that the balance of unlocking research, upgrading mining systems, digging deeper using automated methods...etc, its a pretty solid game.

Another bonus, if you check the forums, the dev is pretty involved in helping the community out and explaining things and looking to improve always. I'd give a 9/10 and I'd recommend to anyone who enjoyed minecraft even a little bit.

reviewText:
'We'll fix all the playability issues after we make enough sales from our full version release.', said no developer twice.

I still don't recommend this game. The developer has now declared that it is finished, and all he'll be doing now is fixing bugs. Here are the remaining issues I have with this game:

1. Consistent UI for machines. This one tripped me up repeatedly. I'd go to a hopper and press E to interact with it, because E opens the UI for pretty much everything else in the game, but the hoppers have no UI. Honestly it makes more sense to use T to Toggle the hopper settings, instead of Throwing selected item on toolbelt into it. Would be Consistent to have a UI for the hoppers, see exactly whats in it, then you could pull specific things from it.

1a. When I finally started tossing iron in, I would have to press Q repeatedly to get everything out of the smelter feed hopper. Then drop the iron in, and if I dropped in anything else, it would randomly select what to make next. So I'd have 1 iron bar, and then a bunch of copper and tin. Although, it's indicative of not random, but a LIFO type system. Last In First Out. Since copper and tin were already automated to that hopper.... So in order to get JUST iron out, I'd have to rotate a belt, empty the hopper, put the iron ore in, wait for the iron ore to finish processing, then rotate the belt back, and drop stuff in again.

2. Mobs pathing through solid objects. Got a nice recording of a slime inside my CPH and also inside the crafting machine. Can't shoot it there.

2a. Kinda got lucky on my base placement, although at the same token, unlucky. It's been a while since I've started a world and had my base nestled at the foot of a mountain on one side. Because the last time that happened, I had to DIG OUT a mountain side, because the green balls of wasp vomit? poop? were flying out of the mountain side at my CPH. Once I dug out enough, I found 2 wasps just chilling inside the mountain, shooting at my CPH. Like solid walls? who cares! we don't have the programming to respect solids. With the slime just willy nilly oozing into and out of my CPH, I'm going to have to assume that nothing else respects solid surfaces either. Arther sure as hell doesnt.

3. No display showing how much charge arther has. At least he's no longer holding a digital sandwich board, cracking jokes, but it's impossible to figure out how much charge he has now, except with a charging station I'm told. It's nice that his text now shows up over your toolbelt, but the sound is a bit obnoxious. Reminds me of an old NES game, where when the characters talk, it would make little blip noises with each character... like Zelda.

4. Arther upgrades still reside in your inventory, and same with suit upgrades I'm assuming, since pressing S in the inventory screen opens a screen for suit upgrades that looks clearly incomplete. I made Arther's power core, why the heck does it live in my inventory? Why doesn't it go to it's own area? IIRC, you can take arther's power core out of your inventory and put it into a storage box. As long as you pick it up before you log out, and it's in your inventory when you launch the game, Arther counts it as having it.

5. Still wish there was a compass. The holobase does seem much better somehow, and there's these red arrows in it, no idea what those are about.

6. Logistics Hoppers, the white ones, although they still didn't spit things out as fast as a Large storage hopper, you could use them to empty a mining drill and send the contents onto a belt. Now they are slower some how. The point of the logistics hopper was to get the ore out of the drill and into transport. Now there's no choice but to stick a storage hopper on them. Which also seem slower in their dispersing speed.

7. New Issue. The automation machines, the stamper, the extruder, the coiler, and PCB maker, used to just zip right along. Since they updated the recipe for laboratory pods, to use 1 PCB per three plates, for a total of 2 PCB to 6 plates for each lab pod... I would build a belt turntable, put a hopper on top of it, stick conveyers on each of the outputs, 3 sides leading to a stamper, 1 leading to the extruder, coiler, PCB maker, have the belts meet at the bottom and move up into a second hopper at the same level as the first one, so you could waste less resources and make lab packs... The whole build occupies slightly more space than the New and improved Behemoth of a CPH. But seeing as the speed of those automation machines is excruciatingly slow now, it causes a backlog, throwing the ratio's off. That's when I decided I'd had enough FCE for a while.

The early game of FCE is Excruciatingly slow. Now with the improvements to the speed of the automation machines, it's going to be EVEN SLOWER...

What FCE feels like to me: Solitary Confinement.
When I shut the game down, I don't feel like I'm leaving FCE, I feel like I'm escaping.

I'm really happy I got two copies at such a cheap price, but to be honest, unless it goes F2P, I'd leave this alone and spend your allowance on a game that was made by a developer that cares more about giving you a quality game, rather than how much money they get for making it.

I will delete comments on this review at my discretion. I'm tired of being harassed by FortressCraft Promoters for expressing my opinion. I'd like to lock it so no further comments can be made. But apparently I don't get that option. So if you love FortressCraft Evolved, write your own review and stay off of mine.

reviewText:
I don't normally write reviews, but this game deserves a review. I absolutly adore this game and has tons of wonderfull ideas and features with literally constant updates. So lets get into the game. What is it? You could say its minecraft but in all honestly...it kind of isnt. It is its own unique game with tons of unique blocks and features that I would love to have in minecraft, that not even modded minecraft can offer. So lets get the good and the bad in the game listed in a nice little list. This is a little lengthy so if you dont want to read all of this and want to know the short version

SHORT Version: Its a good game lots of features and updates, little bugs, if there are it gets fixed pretty quickly, dev streams and listens to his watchers. Also they look at feedback and love to get feedback on the game.

LONG: If you want more depth here you go.

PROS:
-It is constantly updated on a daily baises. There are new features almost weekly and when they did a poll on their twitter, literallythe next day there was a solution and was implemented within a pretty short amount of time. A day or two before it was in the game.

-Bugs are quickly addressed when reported and usually will have a patch in a decent amount of time, depending on how game breaking it is of course.

-Multiple tiers that you work your way through as you go deeper into the world.
-Researching those tiers. The deeper you get the more Research points you get (RP) The more blocks and flora you scan the more you unlock.

-Replayability. Theres a lot of replayability in this game and with constant updates and a lot of features being planned it is always a new experience. (Especially if they add the planned features like space)

-ARTHER. An amazing little robot that you can dress in a top hat, eye monocle and an good looking moustache. Love it! Though hes really useful ingame with status updates and back up power if you run low.

-Much more to list that would just make this ungodly long.

-Multiple game modes that are pretty fun ranging from hardcore and rush mode one or two others that I cant think of atm.

CONS

-Not everything is implemented yet. Some stuff is in there but it hasnt been properly fleshed out. (Though this isnt in early access, it still technically is because of a lot of reasons that you need to game developers point of view to understand. (Which the dev actually explained to us in a stream in depth which gives you a big understanding of the gaming industry. Like the top games make 90% of the money. Even though fortress craft is in the top 500 for steam games they still struggle, so even though this is the con section, I highly suggest if you buy the game you buy the DLC with it to help support them))

-Things can be a little difficult to piece together, even with the handbook, so it may take a little bit of time to figure things out or do a little research (Again its being fleshed out and the handbook is still unfinished so its understable)

-Your kind of stuck in spot defending the same area. Now Im sure they have plans to change that especially when they plan to implement space, so for right now your kind of defending your castle.



Honestly Im just prying cons out of anything I can just to make this seem fair, but there really arent to many cons. If you cant launch the game then talk to the dev. They'll try to help you. Trust me, they want to help you and expand their player base. You can listen into one of their streams and their ideas and viewpoints are really nice to listen into and really put time into their game. It is a bit of a tedious game so it takes time to make things but once you get the hang of it you will surely have fun. This is truly a fantastic game and you should give it a chance. I would honestly even say that this game should be valued way more then 10-15$ for the amount of work they put in, so its a pretty good deal for a game like this.

I'm at 90 something hours played now, and entheusiasm has not faded a bit, i'd just like to add that;
It has been my experience that the devs, to me, seem very open to ideas, but also eager to resolved issues and bugs, i've not had a single bug report or feature request that hasn't recieved attention from the devs yet, seems to me that the developers are very active part of the community.

reviewText:
Do NOT be fooled this is NOT a minecraft ripoff, although it is a blocky game.

This game is about base automation and defending that base from hostiles.

There is an aim and end too this game. Not just dig dig dig.

Yes it has blocks and looks a bit like those other blocky games, but it is not just another rip off".

This game is about
-resource management
-strategy and proritisation
-energy management
-logistics
-efficient layout
-organisation of your base.

Then there is the tower defence side of things too.

Pro's
-process automation
-runs well
-active developer
-developer engages with the players
-developer is passionate about the game
-Survival and creative modes
-generally better graphics than many other blocky games
-Need to think differently to get the hang of automation
-Strategy
-Good for an indie game
-Co-op Multiplayer
-Ongoing development of new features
-Ore scanner - I love the ore scanner!!!

Con's
-Need to think differently
date:
can take time to get head around automation
-Tower defence may not appeal to everyone
-Not perfect (but no worse than a lot of AAA titles I have bought)
-Can lose hours of your day without realising
-Some mobs are a little annoying
-Some animations are glitchy
-Learning curve can seem a bit steep
recommended: until you change the way you think\n\nNOTE I have not had the pleasure trying the multiplayer so I can't comment on the state of it but it is present."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This is an Early Access review and may not reflect the finished product.

After spending aproximately 170 hours in FC:E I feel that I am able to give a fairly accurate review of the current state of the game.

FC:E basically has two modes to play in; Creative and Survival.

Creative
The game looks and feels very similar to many other voxel based games out there - notably Minecraft. However, FC:E stands out from the crowd due to the rather powerful tools that are available to the player. The various tools that you are able to use allow you to make very large and very intricate creations. Copy/Pasting sections of the world can be done very quickly and the ability to create your own blocks using the ingame workshop function allow a level of creativity that has not really been seen in such voxel games previously. I myself have not spent a huge amount of time in creative, however from the limited hours I have put in it became clear rather quick that those who enjoy the freedom of making anything they want will really benefit from these tools and this level of freedom.

Survival
Here's the mode that has stolen a huge amount of my time. In basic terms the survival aspect draws many of the gameplay aspects of those in Minecraft - mining, resource management etc. but here's where FC:E does it differently. A huge focus of FC:E's survival mode is based upon automation and logistics, creating large transport, mining and power networks to build a base and gather resources.

The blocks that exist in the game all have useful functions and although can be a bit daunting at first, are quite easy to use and options for creativity open up once you get the hang of things. If you've played anything like the Feed the Beast modpacks for Minecraft or Factorio then this is the game for you.

Current state of the game
As far as I am aware the engine for this game was built by the developers themselves, allowing them to tailor it to suit the needs of a game like this. It's definately not perfectly optimised, but I have certainly seen worse and the development team are constantly working to improve on this as well as fix bugs, this is to be expected in an Early Access game.

There's a decent amount of content in the game to allow you to spend quite a few hours building and creating what you want. The development cycle is quite fluid and the creators are quite active on the forums, responding to questions, asking for feedback, addressing issues etc.

Mobs and combat are the next big thing to come, which will add quite a bit in terms of gameplay as you will need to defend your base and resources.

Multiplayer in Creative is complete and as far as I'm aware pretty free of bugs. Survival Multiplayer is currently in a working condition although there are some bugs still to be ironed out, but as mentioned previously the devs are quite open and transparent about this and work on this is constant.

Overall I believe this game is a steal at it's current price. Judging from what is already in the game and what has been discussed as the future of FC:E on the forums I really think this game sets itself apart from all the Minecraft clones on the market.

reviewText:
Great game. Been changed so much from last christmas and keeps getting better.

When i 1st played it all you had to do was mine and automate production. That was last year, now just mining is only half of it.

You gotta set up defences with turrets to save ur main base from attack from mobs (the more u produce you more come)
You gotta protect your belts for moving ore up from the mines with turrets also to stop the hiveminds from claiming the ore back (Dont feed the hiveminds!) You've been warned.
The tiers of equipment just keep getting bigger and better when i 1st played tier 1 to tier 3 was all i had now its up to tier 5 with 4.5mil storage!
Multiblock batterys, solar arrays, labs, jet engines and other equipment all to help you advance just keep you wanting to keep building for faster lazers, more lethal turrets and faster energy makers.
Every 300 blocks down or so there are special areas to keep you on ur toes these change the game around .Normal conveyor belts are that depth freeze so you need to upgrade to quicker ways to move ore like minecarts or air tubes.

Its a very fun game where tactics and planning ahead will help you alot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played a few games where you go around gathering resources and building stuff, and this is my favourite.
There are obviously a few games in this genre, and most of the ones I've tried grab you pretty quickly, but they also let you go pretty quickly.

This one, I'm still gripped, and with 37 hours showing, I can see 100's of hours still to be played, there is a lot to do in this, and it is still in active development, which is great.

You start at your home base, with nothing. (As standard.) You wander around, dig stuff up, look for stuff with your scanner. Go back to base. Check out what you've found, discover a few new things to build.
Dig up more stuff, build more stuff, research more stuff. That's the basics.
You can sculpt vast areas, build huge supply chains to feed the machines you build, build bigger machines, set up defenses against the evil natives.

And the more you do, the more you are thinking, ' Just need to do that, then I can do this, and that let's me do that, and then.....' and so it goes. This is a damn big game, and very addictive. Like I said, a lot of games in this genre, but this is the ace in the pack.

Look at the price, it's an absolute bargain!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game wasted so much time of my life but i can say it was worth it. I played it since early stages and seen it evolve and I can say that devs are really working hard to make this game aversome. There are of course bugs, but they not game breaking, and you can easly ignore them.

What i feel playing only survival mode that it's Minecraft on steroids. You get building gun that has VERY long range, infinite world with no bottom and TONS of things to craft. And its not simply digging a few blocks and just making them into some items. You need to use machines to mine ore and coal, power it up and get ore to smelter to get bars for stuff to make. You need to research new machines and tools, and some research proyect requie several machines setup and TONS of power and metal to get.

But the best thing about this game is building automation. You can set up a mine, connect to storage, to engine, load with coal and just come back for ore later. Or you can connect conveyor belts and your ore is transported to smelter, power mine from some sorts of power that is supplied by coal from other mines and your mine will work by itself until it runs out of ore. You can sort your materials, set up complicated structures and watch how its nicely work by itself.

The only think that it's lacking is info how things work. You get short toturial, but basically you need to figure out how each machine works, and there are few dozens of different machines.

This game is great. Maybe not perfect, but it's something I've been looking to play for a long time.

reviewText:
From the brief time I have played this game thus far it is a great game!
It has a great concept and hopefully continues to evolve over the next few years as the developer hopes!

The sad thing here though is that 'out-dated' negative reviews are killing this games progress as reviews do not expire as a game evolves.
I think the review system on Steam is flawed in that respect as it does not retire reviews after a certain period of time, especially if the devs fix the issues, instead if a game has a rocky launch(as this did) it is forever doomed with that mark on its name, even if the dev fixes the issues.
Looking at the negative reviews a lot of the negative reviews are from a long time ago before fixes etc and some things claimed by some users are no longer valid.

That aside,
Gameplay wise, this is a voxel technology/research game.
You need to build systems to power your base, and research new technology to progress.

If you enjoy tech mods in minecraft, this is definately worth a look.
In my opinion it is very generously prices.. I have paid a LOT more for games I have played a lot less off.

This being said, and I will update this review in a week or so after I clock up some more hours.
For the time being, I love the concept and how the game plays and want to support it by adding a positive review!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOkay, I don't really know where to start.  Should I start with the amazing superbuild tool or the awesome weather staff?  I don't know.  I guess I'll start with the pros.  Two of the biggest advantages of FortressCraft (gonna call it fc from now on) are the superbuild tool and the copy/paste tool.  I find both of these EXTREMELY useful.  I can cut the time in half by just holding down ctrl + m1/m2, whereas in a game like Minecraft (I'm probably going to compare/contrast fc to Minecraft a lot in this review) it takes much time, patience, and effort to build things on a large scale.  Also, the way that the terrain spawns is pretty cool.  It moves in to take position instead of just appearing like in Minecraft.  Next, the list of blocks to choose from, in my opinion, is WAY bigger than that of Minecraft.  Configurable Lights, Ore Extractors, heck, even a huge laser gun!  Now before I start getting a lot of nasty comments on this review let me make one thing clear:  I do NOT hate Minecraft.  I actually like it. In some cases, I prefer it over fc, but remember:  this is the pros section. Okay, where was I?  Oh yes, the large library of blocks to choose from.  Ok, so moving on.  I also particularly like the lighting of the certain blocks that produce it.  I also like that the blocks to choose from are mostly sci-fi themed, whereas Minecraft has more of a 'survival' themed list.  Alright, I think that covers the pros!  Now to the cons.  Fc is probably one of the buggiest games that I've ever played.  Now, hold you horses!  This is an EARLY ACCESS game.  You would be a fool to think that an early access game wouldn't be buggy.  I'm sure that all of the glitches/bugs will be gone in time.  Also, after you fly around for a while and you land, your sight radius dramatically shrinks.  Sometimes, I can only see about 10 blocks in front of me, and that's it until I restart.  Again, early access game.  It will get fixed in due time as with the efficiency of the servers.  One last thing:  I know that it's being built/programmed as I type this review, but as of this moment, fc is ENTIRELY single player.  PLEASE don't leave comments about how it's being made right now.  I'm just saying that if you're planning to buy it right now then be prepared to play ALONE.  Obviously, the pros outmatch the cons by a landslide, so I give this game a 2 thumbs up!  I can't wait to see how this game adapts and evolves!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell review, Early July 2015:

Strong Recommend
Gameplay hours: at least 20+
Beta version updates happening weekly or better - very active
Devs active online and taking feedback, adjusting bleeding edge beta almost daily

For now, it is a mining game: you'll have the most fun if you enjoy building an industrial town/machine and gradually automate your mining operation.

Depending on how much you like to tinker, there is at least 20+ hours to get to current endgame (quarry), but that can easily extend as you learn to use the various components to achieve certain things you thought couldn't be done. A lot of the core fun is to figure out a way out of these challenges.

Work has just started on PVE, you might want to avoid the Bleeding edge version of the beta until you master the basics and stick to stable or standard beta until you know what you're doing as they are tweaking things and adding stuff continuously.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter 150+ hours I think I can say : this is a great game! I am a veteran of Minecraft, FTB, MITE and various other custom maps and challenges particularly in survival mode. FCE is similar, but different, to all of these and is centered around your base. You get most of the tools you need from the beginning, and from there it is up to you to build your base around the ore you find, and to automate it. Automation is really cool - you can do things the hard way, yourself, or build a conveyer belt and laser power and it does it all for you! You can just stand there and watch it go, and I often do! After a while you will have to deal with mobs too, so base defences come into play. There is a tech-tree for you to discover which unlocks a lot more of the game, and the limits" are not what you are used to - there is no bedrock

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've played (or are familiar with) Factorio, then Fortresscraft is your kind of game: Only this time you can dig down to the center of the planet (literally) to gather the ores you need.

The Dev seems to be working on this game 24/7 since some updates/bugfixes are happening on almost a daily basis.

There are still things that need further polish though, but even in its current state I've had a lot of fun so far building conveyor belts, exploring caves to locate ores, makeing sure my base had enough power while slowly digging down deeper and deeper ..

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game because it has so much going on and does everything well. You are given just want you need at each stage of the game to work on building up your base toward the next tier of tech. And then on to the next tier. And so on. Each tier brings more fun things to build, optimize, automate, and improve.

The game world is huge and you dig deeper and deeper as your need for more precisous materials grows. The art style is fantastic and many of the machines are wonderfully animated. This game definitely looks amazing and has equally amazing mechanics in how each machine interacts with the others.

The learning curve for the mechanics can be a bit steep but once you get the hang of it you'll spend hours building and changing things and still have more things to do! Defintely many many hours of fun to be had.

For single player I'd give it 9/10 and for multiplayer I'd give it 8/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCaution:  You may forget you own other games!     I have 6 other new games (some big titles) that I bought right before seeing this one on sale.  That was a few weeks ago and I haven't even installed them.  In this game, there is always something else to explore, some cavern to go splunking in, or that next attack you need to prepare your base for.  My favorite part is the fact that this is a giant open world puzzle game that takes constant tweaking to optimize your setup.  There are some unpolished areas and annoyances but the developers are responsive and put out an impressive amount of work for the small team they have.  I can't wait to see what the next patches bring.  This game is well work the price and I have not regretted buying it.  I can't wait to see where the future takes it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a game it works well but... it is a very complex and unfinished game.

now don't get me wrong most of the gameplay is done, but there are a few bugs and most of the documentation needs to get done. and trust me, the documentation is always the last thing you tend to do. it can change and become outdated rather fast, so why would you write something about how something works oneday then change it the next?

needless to say the game is fun and adicting. it is right up my ally and i really wish this was a total conversion mod for minecraft... but it is not, and i don't really care.

for the most part the temerature mechanic is broken. it is not very realistic, and i can't see temps going from 100 degrees celcious to -5. granted it is not unlikely, as a fire in the dead of winter kinda works that way, but you can still feel the heat from a few feet way. then with enclosed spaces, especially underground that heat retains and continues. so if you have a heat source you undergound it should heat better than out in the open, i don't see this happening. it seems that the code does not diferenciate between materials and how enclosed something is. i built a building heated it, and the differance of temperatures was not really that great from when it was not enclosed.

then there are the graphics issues. i want less bloom

now i may sound like i am ratting on it, but i really do like the game, I recommend you give it a try especially is you play minecrat the way i do, with the goal of automatinge EVERYTHING.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game so very very much.
I reckon if you are an older or experienced Minecraft/Technic player you will love this too.

Right now it is in early access and as such there is a variety of things to be sorted but I have watched and dabbled in this over the years and its always been interesting. The Devs keep well on top of this game as well and there is no doubt they are serious about crafting a work of intricate design.

The biggest draw right now, as an early access title, is the machinery. There are still issues with the U.I. and there are gameplay mechanics not yet implimented but the Devs are attentive to their community and listen to suggestions. This is one early access title thats gonna go the distance.

reviewText:
Let's start by saying that this game is still being heavily developed despite being out of early access.   Some of the newer stuff doesn't have icons but besides that the game is basically 100% completable in what constitutes a pretty decent end-game that can take 50-100+ hours to get to, with additional difficulty settings for pretty good replayability.

The game does a good job of combining a minecraft style sandbox with tower defense.  It takes some of the slow and annoying parts of minecraft and removes it and gives the player a lot of tools to assist them with common tasks such as building.  building 50 blocks in a straight line in survival mode is very convienent, not to mention no wait on breaking a block and protection mode from breaking multiblocks.  The grappling hook is quite fun to use and makes grappling up a verticle mining tunnel a lot of fun.  On my 4 year old computer the game runs smoothly even with a lot of stuff going on.

Overall when buying this game remember some developers wait until they have everything that they can possibly do to the game done with before exiting early access, this allows them to make excuses for whatever bugs are in the game.  This developer has done a great job at leaving early access and releasing a very stable main build along with a constantly updated bleeding edge build.  The game might not be as complete as some other games that have exited early access, but it is stable, there is a lot of fun things to do, and my biggest complaint about the game is that $12 is just way too cheap.  I would of gladly paid $20-$30 for it possibly $40

reviewText: A highly polished work in progress game that has consumed many enjoyable hours of my free time. Whilst this game may be sort of like minecraft, it has many defineing differences. Namely the ability to build factories to automate you resource gathering. Also turrets to defend your base and factories from varying types of enemies which as time progresses will be added open. As for the game itself can at times have a bit of a learning curve and be slow in progression at times, but once you figure stuff out it can be quite fun. They community is always happy to help to when you have any issues you need help with.\n\nThere is also a goal to work towards in the end game instead of just hey I found diamonds in minecraft and built the strongest armour. Now what? In the future many more end game goals are planned to be added in and even building of space ships and space station is on the table as one of the possible future additions. The developers are very active too, provideing updates to the game at roughly every to the bleeding edge  branch 1.8 days - 1 week and and activly read their discussions on a day to day bases. All things said I look forward to many fun updates and hours of play from this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR - If you want a finished, bug-free game don't buy it, if you like Minecraft-style games and don't mind waiting for new content and patches buy it. Frustrating at first, but already the developers have made it much better.

I've never played Minecraft but have always wanted to, but when I went to their website and would have had to sign up for an account before I could even see how much the stupid game cost, I became annoyed. I read on another site it was $30 (which I'm not sure is true or not, regardless I became more annoyed). Lo and behold, that same day on the front page of Steam I see FortressCraft for $4. Needless to say I got it.

The first hour was an incredibly frustrating experience because I had absolutely no idea what I was doing and the help menu wasn't helpful at all. Thankfully they have made it much more in-depth, so new users shouldn't have nearly as much trouble as I did. I read a guide and got into it, having quite a bit more fun even though finding ore was tough at first (they have also made this easier, using one key and scrolling to find the ping you want, whereas before there was a key combination for each ping type).

Now that I'm getting my base set up and things automated, I'm having a lot of fun! It's always cool to see your progress so clearly.

There are some bugs which is to be expected since it's an early-access game. Most annoying is that the x64 executable likes to go missing, so I've been playing with x32. There are infrequent crashes, and if you quit when anything is in your smelter the items get lost. Not a bug but slightly annoying when I first started playing: menus that don't completely work. Now that I know the features haven't been implemented it's fine, but before I was clicking and totally confused as to why nothing was happening.

The roadmap the developers have is great, and they seem to be very active here on Steam. Nice to know they're listening! Things I would like to see added are some ideas or guides for power plants and things like that, more detailed graphics (though I'm fine playing with the current ones), and maybe trees that regrow themselves. That would be cool. Seeds and stuff would be neat too.

Anyways, it's a great game and awesome for the price and all the stuff they have planned.
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclaimer: A key was given to us by the developers to review the game.

Hello everybody, Shaun Meyers (Kyo Akiara) here to bring you a short overview of our review for FortressCraft Evolved. If you'd like to read our full, in-depth review, you can find it here: http://www.universalgamingreviews.com/fortresscraft-evolved-overview-and-review/

I've been watching FortressCraft Evolved evolve over the course of its development ever since we first previewed the game quite a long time ago and it's become an incredibly impressive and fun survival based game.

I'm normally the type of person to avoid survival based games in truth but out of the many that we've previewed so far FortressCraft remains one of my favorites, with it's incrediblly massive world to explore, tons of craftable equipment and excellent gameplay, it's a joy to play.

I will also say that the game requires an immense amount of time and patience to really get anywhere and since I lack the patience to create vast mining cities I found myself a bit bored after a while. This doesn't mean the game is bad however, it's just that I can't play a game for that long haha.

Definitely a recommended title though and I enjoyed following its development from a relatively small Early Access title to what it has become now. Still much more to come I imagine, 8.6/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This is a long description, skip to the pros and cons below if you don't want to spend much time on my review)
My initial impression of the game wasn't great, which was largely thanks to the greatest difference between stable and beta branches in a game I've ever seen.   Once I opted into the beta, and selected some easier difficulty options, I found a game that was somewhat similar to some of the tech mods for minecraft, but with far more depth and coherence.   But this game, unlike minecraft, or most other mining games for that matter, requires you to build infrastructure that mines and processes for you, rather than you mining yourself.   The early mining process requires you to locate a sutible ore vein, plop down a ore extracter on it, stick a storage hopper on it, and dump a bunch of power into it, and leave it for about 10 minuites before coming back, recharging it, and taking the ore to refine.
However, every step of that process is automatable, from the very start of the game.   Progression gives you faster, more efficient ways to mine, and automate the mining devices, while encouraging you to dig deeper to get access to more valuable ores, to research and build more advanced and effective machines.

Pros
-Advancing tech keeps you building and modifying structures
-Tower defense aspect adds mid and end game goals
-Scanning and visual tools lets you quickly plan out the most efficent way to set up and debug structures
-All the information needed to progress can be found in game, no immersion breaking forum trips needed
-Large difficulty range
-Multiplayer (Still buggy, will likely be improving with time)
-EXPLOSIVES that you can make as powerful as you have power for (maybe not so great in multiplayer)

Cons
-Not much in the way of a wiki to look up information for optimizing setups, particularly base defense
-Single threaded- hard to run unless your computer has relatively good single thread performance (I have an AMD 3.7 GHz processor, and I have to run it on a lower graphics setting to avoid framerate drops)
-Mob difficulty tends to get grouped- if you want things to fight back, you also have to deal with ore eating mobs that spawn on your conveyers.
-Falling too fast kills you, makes it somewhat hard to go down mineshafts, you have to spend a fair amount of time building and navigating stairwells or platforms
-Some dead spots while waiting for materials to be mined or refined

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow. Just... Wow.

Where to start? This is a really well thought out, high quality game that encourages players to take advantage of its in-depth building system to achieve levels of creativity not found in other craft games.

Mixing exploration with creativity, the game world modes cater for just about any gamer. Survival mode is possibly the most interesting, feeling fresh and challenging to just about any gamer. Survival mode gives a subtle drive to the creative player, besides creating visually stunning environments.

Other modes offer a more relaxed experience, with vareity to suit the player. All modes are customizable in terms of difficulty and resources, in order to create the most suitable game world for the player.

Though in terms of fun, multiplayer is where it's at. Co-op mode is a blast and working alongside your buddies to create and delve is great.

Visually the game blows most other craft games out of the water. The textures have a hand made, consistent quality not often seen in games today, and compliment the models considerably. The sheer level of effort put into the visuals is very noticable, and the torch light in underground areas is pretty cool, gives a real sense of exploration.

The sound effects are great and the music is decent, complimenting gameplay. Listening to the ambient wintery wind howl as you dig and search for resources in survival mode is pretty awesome. Gives a real sense of being in the game.

Best thing though? The deep building system. You can do all kinds of cool stuff like powering generators with coal or materials for equipment energy, check out objects to find their hidden secrets with your laser scanner, craft new gear with materials you find along the way. It has to be seen to be believed really.

Sadly the game has had some slating in the past owing to early beta releases, though in comparison the game has gone leaps and bounds miles away from what it came from (and I hope past reviewers amend their posts.) and exceeded my expectations.

Overall, the game is a great choice for craft game fans and players who want to dip their feet into the world of creative games. Highly recommended.
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great!  They give you a little survival guide that helps you figure out how to survive initially.  Without that there's no way I would've made it.  It's like minecraft with reasonable graphics and a fun space theme.  The worlds are huge, it's easy to get lost and fall down to somewhere far below your base, but that's what the grappling hooks for!

I don't have too many hours into it yet, but so far I haven't seen many bugs.  Occasionally the blocks go transparent if you're standing too close, and the pause menu doesn't seem to actually pause anything.  If you're going to walk away from it for a while, make sure you quit to desktop.  That'll save your world and you won't come back to the game to find you've died and reloaded to a terrible place you were lost at two hours ago.  Can't wait til it's finished, but for a $5 alpha FC can't be beat!

reviewText:
WARNING...This game is so addictive you won't be able to stop....seriously....

For a guy who owns 100+ games on steam with over 10,000 hrs of gameplay I am pleased to announce that this is probably one of the best survival games I have ever played.....

This game doesn't allow you to travel to other planets like Empyrion, it doesnt allow you to travel to the nether like minecraft and it doesnt have mobs chasing you the whole time..... This game is an INDUSTRIAL oriented game, being an engineer makes it even more fun as I plan my production plan for a certain resource. You have questions like how many extractors I need?, how many conveyer belts per resource? should I create a line of robot arms to selectively pick my ores or should I seperate the belts? What  will my production be with one smelter....how about two...how about a hundred? What would the energy requirement be? Can I fullfill it or should I tech up?....and the list just goes on....

Bottom line this game is huge, with thousands of mega projects that you can endorse that can keep you entertained for hundreds of hours.......(note: I just reset my account and I play offline quite often).

This game is a must buy for anyone who loves survival games or even if you want to try one....this game is the way to go.

For all the guys who write hateful reviews, just ♥♥♥♥ off you minecraft lovers.......This game is for big boys.

11/10 Would repel a 100+ Wasp invasion with Arthur.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game because I loved Minecraft with the Buildcraft/Industrialcraft mods. Research and automation are the core progression of this game. As this game is in early access, it does need some polishing and bug squashing.

So far (15hrs), I've found 2 bugs: A minor issue where I had to re-open a UI (such as an inventory screen) to get my cursor to work instead of mouse-look, and an issue in multiplayer where other players could not see my placed blocks. The multiplayer issue was annoying, but the devs are actively working on addessing multiplayer bugs in newer builds.

FortressCraft appears to be built on Mono, instead of the resource heavy Java that Minecraft used. This means it runs in 64-bit, can be multiplatform, and runs very, very smoothly.

Early Access Review

This game still has its bugs.

Despite that, playing it is kind of soothing. I mostly play games like terraria, FTL and minecraft. I make a new review so that I can point out the positive pieces.

Energy system, ores, ingots, intermediate building materials such as PCB:s, copper plates...

It is a bit difficult to move far away from your home base since the power quickly drains. Besides that, I say it's a challenge. So far, I haven't got to the point where I think this game has everything". The most bothersome challenge is moving far away from the home base and finding the resources that you need. reviewText:
Early Access Review

FortressCraft Evolved is not about building your house on an infinite voxel terrain but organising the vertical transportation of ores and power to develop your base. Luckily resources are plentiful as you'll need hundreds of thousands of ingots to accomplish your mission.
As of version 1.19 FortressCraft Evolved is a fully-fledged logistic nightmare which will fulfill the most demanding OCD sufferer. You will find a mix of sandbox, management, research, tower defence and a little survival.

ProjectorGames has been in overdrive for the last months to push the game out of Early Access, and as such you shouldn't take into account comments written before version 1.18. So many things have been added, among which a tiered research, mobs, a tutorial, and an easy mode to accelerate the otherwise challenging and lengthy beginning.

If you like building long assembly lines and accumulate resources to build even more assembly lines, do yourself a favour and buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game so much! Sure it has some bugs and glitches but it is barely done! I want to go over the glitches and bugs before I get to the best parts first just in case someone wants to find out what the issues may be in the game.

The glitches are quite bad sometimes and can seriously affect the gameplay, the glitches come at random moments, usually when you least expect it. We have the problem with not being in control any more, this happens a lot, it causes your player to just fly up into the sky when you press space bar, this can also make it impossible to float back down and usually I just turn the game off after that. We also have the copy and paste option, sometimes it leaves blue and green lights stuck on your walls, sometimes the wall has holes in it where the copy and paste didn't work properly. You've even got a glitch that makes you walk around when you don't want to and you have to just move to a block and wait until the player stops moving, then slowly tap on the 'W' key to make sure he/she doesn't do it again. There is also even on fastest graphics mode it can have a huge drop in frame rates quite rapidly. Don't let this scare you from buying this game.

I think this game is a must have due to its great potential, there aren't a lot of blocks but they are still developing the game and once it is done I am hoping it will have a larger collection of different blocks and materials. It's also a really big world and plenty of worlds for you to make, the copy and paste functions is pure genius and will definantly help to build huge structures! The little robot that follows you is helpful to show what block you currently have and for some reason it looks kind of cute. I'm very serious when I say this game has huge potential! I hope that more people buy this game so they can get more money to develop it better and faster! If you're looking for a game of fun and adventure then this game is for you! If you don't mind the bugs and just get on with it then this is extremely fun, this is my own opinion though so don't take it all to heart. But if anyone wants to join me when they have finished constructing the multiplayer then please feel free to add me. I hope this game gets the recognition it deserves! I remember first playing it on the xbox and it was a really good experience, I felt like I was playing something so different to games like MineCraft and it was a new adventure for me and that is why this game brings back that good feeling of change in the sandbox gaming category.
voteText: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FortressCraft Evolved as its name implies is the evolution of the original installment FortressCraft that appeared on XBLIG in April 2011.  Taking advantage of the power of a modern PC with several times more RAM and processing power compared to that of the aging console, FC:E offers a more expansive world than ever before.

The game builds upon its success from the console version by offering the best creative tools available in any vox game including:
Superbuild - An interface to quickly build geometric structures of thousands of blocks to save time for the detail work
Paint gun - Paint select blocks using nearly any color you could dream
Detail blocks - the micro blocks of the XBLIG version have returned with even more flexibility.  Choose from 2x2 - 8x8 blocks in your detail block design to add a finer touch to your world.  The PC version allows a nearly inexhaustible collection so you'll have plenty of options to add more detail to your world.
Copy and paste - Take a unique design and reproduce it to fill in your world with color or simplify a large project by reducing it to a set of duplicable pieces by copying and pasting elements of your world.
Build2me - Excellent for covering roofs, building bridges, or filling in gaps build2me allows you to place an entire line of blocks from your target all the way to your current location.
High graphical fidelity  - Incredible texture resolution, whole array of shaders, and a lighting engine that must be seen to be believed makes an incredible project look that much better.

All of these provide the player with the tools necessary to build beautiful constructions of a scale that until now has been unimaginable in a vox game.  In this regard it is a huge step forward from the console version.  As of the time of writing this review the primary missing feature from the creative toolbox is animating the detail blocks.  This feature has yet to return but remains on the roadmap so expect it to appear before the full release.  I highly recommend checking out some of the Top rated screenshots to see some of the incredible things players have built already using the engine.

One of the most desired elements that I had waited on with the console version was the development of a survival oriented game to make the most of the engine.  That time has finally come as the survival mode has seen its public debut and with only a few weeks of development time it already shows promise for an entertaining experience that will last many, many hours.  The player is dropped into a world where the environment itself is hostile.

The early game has the player battling the cold by sustaining a supply of energy to power his high tech hazard suit to prevent freezing to death by hypothermia.  The suit also appears to be designed for heat, radiation, low oxygen levels, and toxic environments so expect to see a variety of hazards to face from the world itself.  As of the time of writing the cold is the only threat.  Although the suit can be heated up by standing on a torch there is no danger from heat yet.  It will attempt to consume energy to keep you cool however.

The gameplay centers around the idea of your suit energy being your life and that venturing far from your main energy network is a great risk.  You'll spend much of your time developing a network of power distribution to your mining network which is driven by machines called extractors which collect ore from resource nodes albeit at a slow pace.  This process is slower than the player's own mining ability however it is more efficient and automated as long as you sustain the machines with energy.  Later on you gain the ability to make batteries to store power and provide it to your machines, lasers which are used to move power between batteries, a generator for burning coal to produce power, hoppers to collect the resources from the extractors, and robots to move items among the hoppers.  The end result is the complete automation of your mining operations and the ability to generate and move energy around your base of operations to keep everything alive and moving including yourself!

A few other relevant bits about the mode: torches can be placed as a source of light and heat.  They serve as little beacons of safety in the harsh world.  The player is provided with a grappling hook to quickly climb from the depths as the world goes down many light years.  Surival mode currently only utilizes the first several hundred blocks down but will eventually stretch to several thousand meters underground.  The player has a handy ore/cave sensor which consumes a quarter of your suit energy but provides an indicator of the closest ore/cave from the player.  This removes some of the tedium associated with finding resources and just getting about underground.

All of this is only after about a month of development.  There is already a list of planned features to expand upon the mode including suit upgrades such as increased energy storage, greater insulation from the cold, upgrades to the ore sensor to identify specific ore types, and more.  The first mob was added to the game which is a real treat.  The details of which I won't provide here as they are more fun to discover on your own. :)  He isn't much of a threat yet but I'm sure that will change as the tools necessary to combat him are added.  In the current state it takes several hours to proceed through the current tech tree and with additional features promising to fill out the game the survival mode is shaping up to be an incredibly entertaining experience that will be even more fun with friends given the natural scale of the game.

It is now I should probably place a reminder here of the normal warnings of early access games.  This is an early access title so it isn't complete yet.  Among the features still missing that is probably most desirable is multiplayer.  It is on the roadmap and even in development right now.  The devs have the game roadmap[www.fortresscraft.com] including multiplayer progress on their website where you can keep track of progress if you don't wish to buy in immediately.  As mentioned above the animations are not available for detail blocks and survival mode is only a month into development.  Other areas that still need work include the menus where many options are still unavailable and do not use a mouse interface yet.

In the end I guess the question that matters most is: Is it worth it?  If you enjoyed the creative experience offered by the XBLIG version or are looking for a more powerful block builder than you can get with other PC titles then FC:E is already a must buy.  If the survival experience is more what you are after then the answer isn't as clear.  Although the game is progressing very quickly it is still far from complete and there are many features required to fill out the experience.  There is also a lot of bug fixing and optimization needed as so much is being thrown into the game so quickly.  If you absolutely must have the end result then it is worth buying now at the introductory rate which is said to be 40% of the final price and will increase with each major milestone.  If you still are unsure then be sure to check out the forums regularly as new patches are released multiple times a week with fixes and new content.  At the rate the game is currently moving it will be making a big name for itself in voxel gaming this year.

reviewText:
Building, automation, and exploration
The game just left Early Access, but it's far from being done. I mean that in a good way: The devs are committed to adding features as long as they can afford to.

Your job in this game is to build a massive industrial complex to save yourself and escape the hostile planet you've crashed on. If you find yourself doing something tedious, there's probably a machine you can use to do it for you instead.

Pros:
Zillions of machines to automate your base
Fun tower defense aspect can be ignored if you don't like it
World size is basically unlimited. Dig as deep as you can!
Good graphics
Multiplayer
Creative mode allows construction of amazing things
Cons:
Documentation is mediocre. (Used to be poor, so it's improving.) Best source of info is the Steam forum, which is disorganized because it's a forum.
There are some rough spots in scaling your industrial output. There are no machines to gracefully handle thousands of resources. (But they're working on it.)
Not much plot or story; if that's what you're looking for, it's not here.

reviewText:
First up, I have 183 hours playing this game so far, it's by far my favourite block game there has been so far.
If you enjoyed modding Minecraft with things like machines and power, then this is basically that done properly.
For anyone thinking or expecting a Minecraft clone however - it's far far from Minecraft's gameplay.

The immense fun in this game comes from building bigger and bigger..  More power required, more ore required.. More, more, MORE!  You always want and need more!  But that's a balanced gradual process and before long you have a sprawling power network powering deep mines and a massive turret network on the surface to defend against the planet's creatures' attacks which ramp up and up as you grow.

It's constantly being developed (sometimes 3-4 patches a day on the bleeding edge line) and the main dev is fantastic and very active on the steam forum, always listening to and answering comments.
If a bad bug is spotted it's usually fixed that day, sometimes within the hour even.  I wish all games had development this great.

TL;DR..
Buy it now.

reviewText:
A very good base building sandbox game.  The developer is very active and actually reads and responds in the forums which is a big plus to me.  There are updates about every 2~3 weeks now that it has been released, which I am ok with (I am refering to the Patch # content, which are rather large updates).

A lot of people have compared it to minecraft but main difference is that there is no weapon or armor upgrade for your character.  This is mainly because this is more of a tower defense type game, so if you are looking for a shooter this won't be it.

My only gripe with the game is that you cannot move your starting Central Power Hub (CPH) which basically forces you to build at your start point since that is what you have to protect.  It would be nice if you could relocate your base.
