reviewText:
I became addicted to this game in the oddest way. There were probably three or four minutes in the entire day of total playtime that I actually enjoyed myself. But the more I invested myself in the game, the more I felt determined to get something out of it, and the more time I shoved into it. I spent almost all of yesterday (5/16/2016) playing, desperately trying to make progress.
There are several problems with making progress.
First off, this is not a single player game. It may have the ability to be played single player, but it's not single player. There just isn't enough progress for it to be single player. In order to make a reasonable amount of progress on my own, I edited files in order to vastly speed up my gameplay. Somehow, that made it go from very boring to incredibly boring.
Nothing happens quickly on your own. Even with the game settings set all the way to the quickest, easiest, fastest settings. You need 32 bars of something to build x. Well, settle in, that'll take a while unless you've already got five or six systems running. And it's not like setting those up is quick. Or cheap.
And don't get me started on how long it takes to research pretty much anything once you've got the laboratory. The projects take ages to complete, and enough resources that after a day of highly sped-up gameplay, I was barely able to make some of it.
But that's not the worst part about this game.
This game is NOT finished. This game was early-access, and still should be! It's nowhere near complete. I find bugs everywhere I go. I come back to my base and all my turrets are facing firmly in one direction, a giant laser firing out. The ship I crashed in is on fire (it's only been two months in-game since I landed, I'm sure that's normal). The CPH is projecting some kind of field that is making it awfully hard to see. Various other things are making all sorts of very bright frames of animation that make it practically impossible for me to see what the hell is happening in my base.
My laser turrets are still working fine. It's just impossible to tell that.
I place another laser turret on top of another block I've placed, and all the bugs disappear in an instant.
Before I do that, the ship hurts me if I get too close.
Now? No worries, I can walk straight through it.
I assure you, this is one of many, many bugs that I've encountered. The list got so long I didn't bother remembering them.
Then, there's the simple fact that some things are either badly implemented, have missing icons, mismatched icons, or maybe their help file doesn't exist.
Make some iron pipe if you can. Or find something that requires iron pipe and look at the picture. As of this moment, the picture is a big red x and the words NO ICON". Go grab some cave flora from the cold or toxic caverns. One of each. Then
date: place them. Place them against a wall
hoursPlayed: so they're actually right-side-up. Don't ask why. Now
voteText: compare the flora you just placed to the icon. They're mismatched. A is B
helpfulPercent: B is A
votesHelpful: C is D
votesTotal: etc.\nHow about auto-excavators? Place one on a wall
votesFunny: and you'll probably think it can dig a 3x3 hole horizontally. Maybe if you place it on the ceiling

column16: instead of up! Why would you think that? Because the column of light indicating where it can dig shows that!\nYou'd be wrong. Once you power it up
column17: no matter where you're trying to 'aim' it

reviewText:
After a relatively short scene-setting intro and a very quick tutorial, FortressCraft Evolved has handed you the basics and expects you to get on with it, which is a refreshing change from too many games with 20 minute pause-button press-pause tutorials that seem to be the trend recently.

That said, the tutorial does give you the basics of how to figure everything else out for yourself with fairly extensive in-game help and tooltips, so with a bit of trial and error along the way, for which the game imposes no penalties on the easy difficulty settings (my personal recommendation until you know what you're doing), you soon get into the swing of it.

Automation is a major part of the game, and your strategy of implementing this will heavily determine the pace of the game. Want it to go faster? Simply increase whatever factor is limiting your progress, be it power, materials, or machine throughput.

Just as you're getting the hang of all this, you'll come across the Threat Analyser and probably end up building one out of curiosity. This will warn you of incoming attacks and keep you informed as to how much attention your base is drawing from the native life forms. Very useful in determining when you really need to change your focus to building defences against said life forms, but again on the easier settings the only penalty for failure is that it temporarily stops your source of comepletely free power.

I've restarted this game several times now, because after developing my base setup a certain way I get further then come up with a better way to do things, which would almost certainly be easier if I did it from the very beginning. The fact that this game can still cause such epiphanies is to me a mark of a very well thought out game indeed.  That said, I could just tear it all apart with no penalty, and rebuild, but I prefer a clean slate.

The game is undergoiong continual development on a daily basis. This does not mean that the game is unfinished, having watched the developer's daily live streams of the work being done I can say that it if the game had stayed in Early Access until he ran out of ideas and had implemented all the current thoughts he has for late-game content, it would still be Early Access ten years from now, and the game already far surpasses many titles that I've seen launched from EA.

It's true that the developer is planning explansion packs as a way to introduce large chunks of extra content to the game, and a lot of people have slammed this decision, despite the fact that he has clearly said that if he can afford to do so, these will be free expansion packs rather than paid.  Given how many games are released in an almost episodic fashion these days, this is by no means unreasonable, especially given the exceptional value for money the FCE represents. How many games can give hundreds of hours of enjoyment for £10?

At this price give it a try, it's a steal and if you enjoy any kind of tower defence, voxel building, crafting, gathering or logistics/assembly line games you should have a blast.

Tl/dr: A great game that keeps getting better.
voteText: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've ever wondered if the Unity3D engine can do games like Minecraft, then this game answers that question. Its a port of a game that's been on consoles for some time now, and is still a work in progess so things are going to be pretty rough. Despite its shortcomings this game has a lot of potential to be serious competition for Minecraft, which up until now has had no real competition on the PC side.

There are things that need to be fixed. You still get the Creative Mode item list in Survival Mode, making it hard to determine which blocks you have available, and you cannot use the mouse in your inventory screen. In fact, you can't use the mouse in any of the interfaces for the game except for the ESC button menu while in-game. This needs to be addressed, especially for this PC port of the game.

As I said, this game has massive potential, so while its not quite ready yet if you buy the game now you're helping the developers out so they can finish it that much faster. So, while its very rough as an alpha this is one worth investing in.

reviewText:
Give this guy your money. It's like a cross between Factorio and Minecraft like others have said, a couple key features that really stand out though. First is the fact I'm pretty sure there's no limit to how deep you can dig. Gameplay zones right now go as deep as what, 1000 blocks or something? A minecraft map is 128 blocks from the tip top of the ceiling to the very bottom of bedrock, with only around 60-80 of those being actual land blocks and not empty space. In Fortresscraft, you keep digging down to progress further in the game, and right now I think the last zone is around 1000 blocks or so with plans to develop layers even deeper than that.

Second is the uh, the holoview or whatever, where you hit a button and you can see all your constructions through walls. So when you're digging around and trying to get all your power lines to match up underground, you don't have to count blocks. You just hit a button and bam, everything is visible. It's truly amazing. Also yes, there's elevators.

If you have any interest in this kind of thing whatsoever, give this man your money. Even in its current state you'll have a blast messing around with stuff, and future plans to develop it into a full PVP base-versus-base type game have already been stated, so seriously, give this guy your money. If development ever makes it that far, this will be one of the greatest games ever made. It's already extremely well optimized and well put together as-is. Absolutely worth the asking price.

reviewText: Similar to minecraft, in that it is a block based, 1m x 1m x 1m type game. The similarities disappear shortly after that. The build gun is an amazing tool for building or removing blocks at long range and is capable of building large platforms or walls very quickly. Most of the game is based on automation of resources or manufacturing, similar to Factorio. The game play in single player seems to flow through 3 distinct types of gameplay: you start off in a survival game, fighting the elements and trying to just manage; mid-game is filled with automation of all sorts, from power generation and transport, to quarrying, refining materials you obtain, and auto-crafting items; end-game is similar to a tower defense game, fighting hordes of enemies, trying to keep them from destroying your Central Power Hub and resetting the charge on your end-game structure. I thoroughly enjoy it, and can easily say that it's worth the full price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/fortresscraft-evolved-first-impressions/
Note: These are my first impressions based off of my first play session

Fortresscraft was first released in 2011, on the Xbox 360 and went on to become one of the most downloaded Xbox Arcade games ever. Fortresscraft Evolved is a complete remake of the original Fortresscraft in the Unity engine and was released on Steam Dec 10, 2013.

A lot of people will go ahead and compare this game to Minecraft and, while it does share some similarities with my all-time favorite game, it is actually quite different, especially in terms of creative building. There is a survival mode in the game, but when I tried to start a new world with it, I was placed in creative mode. No idea why that happened.

The creative mechanics in the game are fantastic. There are many features that make building a lot easier than what you'd probably expect from a game like this (try shift+left clicking with a block in hand). I was even able to whip up a quick tree house in about 30 seconds, and this was no ordinary tree house, it was massive. I really love what the devs did to make creative building as painless as possible.

The game does have some technical issues however, with the game sound being my major complaint. They seemed to lag behind. Oh, and is there supposed to be game music? I heard some at one point, but, other than that, it appears to be nonexistent.

Anyways, the game is fun, if you know what you're doing. The survival mode, however, simply is not as fun as I had expected it to be. Recommended purely for its creative capabilities!

reviewText:
Wow, where to begin with this game. Let me first start with my opinion. I love this game. However, I can not recomend it as of yet. I spent 24 hours fo game time as of the time I've written this, and I still don't really have a clue what's going on. It's advertised as a tower defense mincraft clone, but I've never played minecraft, so I'm not really sure if it is. I really like the idea of having to dig to find minerals, the blocks you can remove, the things you can research, but I don't like having to search outside the game or go through a million other steps to get a general idea of what I should be doing.

Let's start off with the 10 second tutorial. It sucks so bad, after the first time I booted the game up and watched the unskippable (in this day and age, really?!) opening scene, I had no real idea of what to do or how. Sure, there is a help menu that gradually fills up with more information as you need it, but isn't the point of the tutorial to teach you what you need to know? There's no real explination of day or night, no real explination of what you can craft, and nothing tells you what you're research unlocks until you've already researched it.

Now the community is great, and all the answers can be found someplace, but to me, that takes time away from the game. It's advertised as a tower defense, but it's more like a base defense, eventually. I'm not going to get into the nitty gritty, but this game needs a ton of polish before I can actually recommend it to anyone. The learning curve is HUGE in this game, and I'm still finding things out the more I play, but if that's your thing, feel free.

Update: With the new patch that came out, I truly do love this game more. I still can't recommend it though until it does some serious polishing. No game ever should keep basic things away from the player, and that level of transparency is exactly what this games lacks. It's also unbelievably slow. I've been playing for days and there are still things that are hidden from me and I have no idea what they do until I actually spend the 5-6 hours unlocking it. As a player, it's truly the only reason I keep this game thumbs down.
voteText: 14 of 24 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's like minecraft, but without all the boring ♥♥♥♥.

Dear lord, this game is fun. It has all of the creative potential of minecraft, but automation removes all the boring negatives like manually mining and smelting and even building block by block. Instead of wasting time on that boring nonsense, FortressCraft Evolved allows you to focus on advancing your tech, building your base, and defeating your enemies!

There are tons of awesome aspects of the tech aspect of this game, with my favorite being the ability to build blocks from a specified block to your location using control-click. AFAIK, minecraft doesn't let you do this. At least, it didn't back in the day when I played it. Also, this game has a grappling hook. Let me repeat that for you. THIS GAME HAS A GRAPPLING HOOK. AND YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE TO UNLOCK IT. There are multiple power source types for your machine, and your enemies (bees native to the world you're stranded on) provide you with valuable building materials. There's a lot of variety in every aspect of the game: building, smelting, mining, etc.

Also, this game is gorgeous for what it is. I'm running it on an intel g3258 that I haven't gotten around to overclocking yet and an AMD r9 270 and it still runs decently on high-ish settings. And it works on linux! :D

There are a lot of complaints from earlier in the game's development about the creator abandoning the project. He came back, and has been consistently releasing updates since the beginning of the year. He's a bit snarky, but he's really fun to interact with, and he actually listens to player feedback.

Basically, this game is everything an indy game should be. Fun, inventive, varied, cheap, and available across all platforms. What are you waiting for?? Buy it!

reviewText:
This game is a fun sandbox game with a mainly mechanical focus. You'll certainly feel the grind early on, as you work to gather resources. Getting to know the controls is a must; mining ores using only the automatic things is slow, so make sure to read through the controls to get to know all the stuff you can do to save time (Superdig is invaluable). I never really got to any of the advanced machinery, as the grind just got a tad boring. Also, the creative mode's fun, I guess. All the block textures are highly situational, which is my main gripe with the game. Other than that, it's a fine game.

I'd recommend this game to anybody with some time to burn (this game is great for passing time; one moment it'll be 8PM and the next it's 2AM) and a bit of money to spare. It's nothing outstanding, but it is certainly the sort of game you can use as a filler between games.

EDIT: After some of the more recent updates, I've found that the game can be a fair bit more fun. I found the combat (while flawed in some areas, like the lack of a crosshair and the charged shot doing nothing more than the regular shot) to be rather fun.

Also, after messing around in creative (I was exclusively playing survival to this point) I found that the detail blocks have been MASSIVELY improved since Chapter 1. The ability to have the block textures as either scaled or not is a brilliant addition, because that was one of my main issues with the original. The detail blocks can actually be used for seamless detailing, which is brilliant.

It certainly is an improvement on Chapter 1 in near enough every way, and (in some ways) is better than Minecraft for building larger creations. With the addition of texture pack support, I should hopefully be able to customise the game to the way I would like, which is a brilliant feature.

Overall, I'm changing my rating from time waster" to "generally good game". It's a good game in pretty much all aspects (if a little buggy at times. I'm looking at you
date: spiderbot on hills. But that's just hilarious) and great in others."

reviewText:
Well... This will be complicated.

First off, full disclosure: I recieved this game from the Dev after expressing my doubts and disbelief on the forums. The topic can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/254200/discussions/0/528398719792747294/

And on to the review itself...

Fortresscraft is something I have difficulty playing objectively. I snagged the original back when I was a gamer on the Xbox 360 before switching to PC, and I was not impressed. It was a 'Minecraft clone', in the sense that it was blocky and HD and there was not much value in it other than blowing up the water and watching the broken physics for it cause it to spread across the entire world, but only after you had reloaded the level.

Upon seeing this title on Steam, I was, understandably, not impressed. So, after downloading the Dev-given game and booting it up, I found a few things out.

First, the game has some derps and issues. The tutorial can be confusing and derped at times, leaving you with little idea of what to do. I have heard there's a wiki up at this point, but there was not one when I started.

You enter with little idea of how to do things, which can honestly be great. I've played Dwarf Fortress with less. Still, however, it's not a great introduction.

Further on, I can see hints that this is something that I might enjoy and thrive in if I could only get it, for lack of a better word. It's not that the game is complex, it's that I just can't figure out where to go, after a bit. So many things that would really improve things for me are either missing, or I am not finding them.

I know, and I can see, that this is really a good game, especially where it came from. I did have a bit of fun, and the mechanics are mostly solid, but I just couldn't get very far.

Overall, the reason this is 'recommended' is because, in the end, I know it's a good game. It just isn't my type of game. I'll stick with my complex RTS addiction for my fix.

In numbers: 6/10. Above average, at least. Steam really needs a 'mixed' review setting.

reviewText: This review is from when I played the game back before the semester started when it was still in early access. This game is interesting and has some fun ideas. If you liked the old Tekkit Minecraft mod then you will like this game as well. The game involves finding resources, automating those resources to bring it back to base, and setting up defenses against a world that doesn't like you. A very fun game but, like minecraft, will absorb your time. If you need to keep a GPA up I would probably wait till a break to play the game, otherwise give it a try.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I normally don't review many games, however, I feel like this one deserves it. It's not your standard dig and build. You really need to put thought into how to get ahead.  A lot of exploring to research new ore types.
Pros:
- Really colourful graphics and textures
- Environmental effects (AFK in the middle of no where with no heat... you'll die of hypothermia)
- Huge environment
- Tons of items to research/build/craft

Cons (1 dev? And still alpha)
- Not very intuitive controls (took awhile to figure out what each button did)
- Not many creatures to hunt/kill

Overall, I find this game very enjoyable and hope to see the production continue. Mod support... could only imagine the stuff people could make.

For the price, and to support an indie dev... definitely worth it.
(And yes, low hours shown on Steam, but I do play this offline and on my other computer so it's not being added to the total)

recommended:

reviewText:
One of the best games of this type now. If you played Minecraft with tech mods (IC2, TE, Gregtech) and liked it, you will love this game.
Very cool cold and toxic caverns, a lot of fun exploring big caves without any map.
Good-balanced hard mode, which is rare, provides nice challenge for automation and logistics, and at least 300 hours of gameplay for sure, even more if you go blind without any info. Sadly no survival challenge except defending base (which can be ignored until you need loot from mobs, or charge OET, which is deep end-game)

Would i spend 520 more hours designing logistics network and automation? Damn yes, 10/10 Arthers , would also suggest for everyone to buy DLC and support DjArcas for his massive work and answering our stupid questions on stream :)

reviewText: Over 900 hours in.... If you like Minecraft you will quickly become addicted to this game!  The game goes well above and beyond the simplicty of Minecraft. Picture yourself crashing on snow-covered alien planet.... Survival is paramount! Research your surroundings, gather resources, build a fortress, improve your fortress, dig deeper, research, develop, edit, fail, re-edit, outfit, try not to get yourself killed in the process, heart-pounding darkness, ledges, and deep dangers.  Then there are the aliens to deal with.... not generally after you - rather your base - course if your Central Processing Unit is destroyed - you die.... Research power advances, build weapons, mine deeper ore, improve your situation - survive!  That's just in the first stage....  The game is challenging and becomes more complex as you play. That complexity can also lead to frustration, especially at the end of stage one - powering up the Orbital Transmission Tower while balancing and re-balancing your defenses but overall this is a game that forces you to think, awake - asleep....

reviewText: Before continuing into the meat of this review there is something you need to be aware of, while this game is aesthetically similar to minecraft it needs to be made clear that it is not a clone. The world made of cubes and mining had already been around before minecraft, and moreover its an aesthetic that is not something minecraft owns. If you can't get past the all cube based games are minecraft copies" then stop reading here
date:
onto the meat.

Pros:

recommended: the option to play with high or low difficulty in finding ore
hoursPlayed: the strength of hostiles

helpfulPercent: they are exactly what should be in a game like this
votesHelpful: instead of only straight forward hit you and the face type ememies you have an enemy that will attach itself to your conveyor belts and such and devour all your ores making its nest ( the hivemind ) larger

column16: one of the most tedious  hardships one usually faces in "cube games"
column17: this game offers a high powered grappling hook
column18: you can dig straight down and then grapple back up

you will feel a level of satisfaction on par with properly heating a plate of pizza rolls and not burning your tongue and throat.

it is misleading and could be the leave a sour impression depending on whether you did your research or not.

Conclusion:

I gave an equal number of pros and cons

reviewText:
EDITGetting a trojan warning from fortresscraft's .exe  [See Comment section]
How peculiar:
http://puu.sh/nIHwo/d104fdc49a.png

IntroductionComing into FortressCraft my only survival building game experience has been minecraft. So I'd like to say my expectations were high. I had read FC Evolved was similar to Tekkit modded minecraft and I was getting excited.
Firstly I dislike space themed anything - and this is definitely space themed - but I've found it to be fine.

My first 10mins of gameplay I was confused AF. It's fun to learn and work out what you have to do - which could be avoided by watching a gameplay of FC Evolved on YT, but I wanted to throw myself into the deep end. I'm at 20+hrs in, 17hrs of which in this one world, where I like to pretend I know what I'm doing. And I feel I've barely scratched the surface.  Once you figure out a methodology and approach, and are fast acting on it, I think you could have a world up and running a LOT faster than what I've done in this first attempt - and that's one of the selling points, become efficient.

Pros/ConsPros:
+ Loads of gameplay
+Looks pretty [I run at good, and occasionally stutters - my gfx card runs Farcry 4 at decent settings]
+I love the mobility [compared to MC]
+I love the grappling hook mechanic
+I love ctrl+clicking to build 30blocks in a straight line
+I love seeing a base grow and become automated
+I love pressing K to find where I placed that ore extractor, because I totally forgot where I put it
+Addicting gameplay
+Always something to do/alter/change/move/collect/kill/mine/ping
+You can leave it in the background/ALTTab and even on single player, the world continues to simulate - so if you have automated mining set up, you can do other things away from your PC and come back to collect smelted ores.

Cons:
-I wish there was lights - early on. Throwing a bright green torch is ugly and hurts my eyes :')
-I wish conveyor belts could be placed with ctrl+click, as that would save me time
-I wish the music was better? A lot of annoying sounds. I find it actually nicer to play with sound off becaues of this.
- Confusing progression.

Overall, I paid ~$15.00 for it[?], and it has been worth it. I plan to put a lot more hours in.

PS.S.
I walked upto that giant squid monster and instantly died. My reasoning being I saw an unknown block at it's centre and I wanted to collect it :^).

reviewText:
Hey guys,
this is my first review ever. Really like this game. I find it hard to remain interested in games after a day of smashing them, but im still playing this one. So that says something pretty big. Also my mrs is starting to hate this game as im on it too much.

Pros
-Exceptionally fast load time. once you double click the games shortcut, you are in world within a 15-20 seconds. great for those of us impatient or busy people. I really really hate bull**** loadtimes. I want to play a game not make a cup of coffee and come back while waiting for the main menu.

-Good game progression.  for once a game that doesnt bog you down waiting for research, construction, or resource gathering/grinding. It has a nice balance of automation to the point where all that stuff can be done while you are off exploring. Ive often been off exploring a cavern and come back only to find that the slowest part of the system is myself and it is easy to get to the point of automation that most things become trivial (Wtf do i do with 5k copper now?)

-enemies and death. you can make the game as hard as you like, and the consequences of death as permanent or trivial as you like in world gen. Which is really nice when you are still learning how to grapple around a massive cavern or falling down a really big hole.

- The world. OMFG it is huge. The underground caverns are enormous, like really really really big and the terrain changes with depth, always serving up something different.

-in game help. it is incredibly intuitive. It could be a little more indepth with some items but still very well thought out and just a blessing.

-holobase function. you can track realtime how your network is functioning and where any bottlenecks are

-good steam community who have most answers for you.

-developer that is active on forums and takes interest in our feedback.

cons

-there is no way to pause the game as yet. you can camp out next to a torch or leave and come back (which is not that big of a deal due to fast load times) but pause would be awesome when you have the mrs trying to talk to you or a baby screaming at you. I understand the dev has said that it is a survival game but it could be a deal breaker for some gamers.

-controls take a while to get used to. now and again im still trying to access hoppers with e.

-the options could be a little more in depth with the sounds and music. took  google to find out how to turn off music (ctrl -m)

-a coordinate system would make digging holes to your mining operations soo much easier.

all in all a great early access game. very well thought out and designed. a clear development roadmap and it gives you what it promises. anyway back to the mrs tasks

reviewText:
Having never played minecraft, I come at this game fresh.  If you like a nice logistics game with good graphics and a blocky environment, I recommend this game.  It's fun and moderately challenging.  I do however feel it isn't really fully fleshed out.  There isn't enough challenge.  Unless you are grossly incompetent, you won't lose the game, and there is no feeling of dread that you are in deep doo doo and might lose.

I do recommend the game and I do find it fun, but after awhile you realize you have reached a point where you have so many resources, you just don't have to worry about nothing and the challenge is all gone.

What the game needs is random events of some type that force you to cope with the unpredictable, or some sort of boss creature that attacks once in a while and might destroy parts of your base.

reviewText:
So after more than 100 hours in game, I can finally make my review:

This game is very unique (in my opinion) to the other games. This game MAY be blocky as minecraft, but the textures are detailed, and pretty, with out them being blocks. They do have blocky hit box, but hitboxes aren't that important ;). So beck to the topic. You can build BIG mining operations, and factories, and what not, on pretty much anything. Because of the worlds size that is 200 LIGHT YEARS (or 1892146155423912000 meters !) long in every direction from spawn, you can build what ever. It's kind of hard and challenging to start up, but when you get a bit automated, you are all good (and challenges are fun, right?).

Now lets talk about mining. You get an ore extractor, that mines ore veins. Each ore vein is different in size. Some can be up to 32 mil. ore!. That is going to last a very long while. But to do that you need to send power down, and then with conveyors, pipes, ore matter movers, up to the surface and smelt it.

Goal in this game (right now) is to kill 4 overminds, with orbital strike. Now there is at least 100h of gameplay. But this is not like factorio (I still love Factorio tho), that you win, and not play anymore. If you win here, you can still do stuff! But if you kill them, nothing will attack you (for now)

Now about updates and performance. Well, updates are often, and also you have different betas" to play on

reviewText: First couple minutes of the game I had absolutely no idea what was going on. It didn't take me too long to get used to all the games mechanics. Before long I was rolling around in piles of my Ingots. With each research complete I was getting more and more excited to see what the end-game would be. Now that I have gotten to that point I have a huge challenge ahead of me and I can’t wait to see what I can do with it. I've had the game for 4 days with roughly 90 hours of gameplay. Most addicted I’ve gotten to a game in a long time. Buy it!

reviewText: Before continuing into the meat of this review there is something you need to be aware of, while this game is aesthetically similar to minecraft it needs to be made clear that it is not a clone. The world made of cubes and mining had already been around before minecraft, and moreover its an aesthetic that is not something minecraft owns. If you can't get past the all cube based games are minecraft copies" then stop reading here
date:
onto the meat.

Pros:

1. This is a common one yet still important
recommended: the option to play with high or low difficulty in finding ore
hoursPlayed: the strength of hostiles
voteText: and even obtaining the energy you will so dearly need throughout the game. This is important as being able to enjoy the game from both a higher level and casual standpoint is a must.\n\n2. The hostiles
helpfulPercent: they are exactly what should be in a game like this
votesHelpful: instead of only straight forward hit you and the face type ememies you have an enemy that will attach itself to your conveyor belts and such and devour all your ores making its nest ( the hivemind ) larger
votesTotal: and a little stealth cube thing that will drain power from your mining set up underground. Better yet
votesFunny: they still include a straight forward hit you in the face mob
commentsCount: and a little or dropping resource mob to boot for your tin needs.\n\n3. Instead of making you dig out a staircase
column16: one of the most tedious  hardships one usually faces in "cube games"
column17: this game offers a high powered grappling hook
column18: you can dig straight down and then grapple back up
column19: this may seem overpowered however it will already take you quite some time to acquire resources and set up your automated mining and power system
column20: if getting back to the surface were to take forever each time this game would be rendered unplayable by those of us who just dont have enough time.\n\n4. The automation that can be achieved in this game is satisfying
column21: when you go from having to run back in forth to your copper mine set up to watching the copper roll in on a conveyor into your hopper then into your smelter
column22: and at the moment you are looking at the 200+ stack of copper
column23:
you will feel a level of satisfaction on par with properly heating a plate of pizza rolls and not burning your tongue and throat.

Cons:

1. Despite what I said earlier about the hostiles
column24: the game could probably use a bit more in this area
column25: if you know what you are doing they are pretty easy to handle as is
column26: there doesnt need to be too much more of this but some for sure.\n\n2. The learning curve
column27: if you dont watch some videos
column28: you are likely to flounder about having no idea what you are doing
column29: this does hurt the game quite a bit. If you are against checking out some videos to figure things out this might be the deciding factor for you.\n\n3. Being a little to intense with the autmation
column30: if you arent a fan creating (sometimes) complex systems to acquire
column32: and convert your ore into useful objects then this game just isnt for you.\n\n4. The name
column33: if you have played the old fortresscraft
column34: then you go in expecting something quite different from what you will get
column35:
it is misleading and could be the leave a sour impression depending on whether you did your research or not.

Conclusion:

I gave an equal number of pros and cons
column36: what comes down to is if you enjoy automation
column38: then theres a pretty high chance you will enjoy this game
column40: and if you arent into that
column41: but you still want to give it a go

reviewText: Fantastic game if you like building factories and advancing through a tech tree. This is the best mining/crafting/base-building game I've seen yet! At time of writing, there's over 20 hours of non-grindy mining and crafting before you get to the grindy end-game content. It's still being worked on, but the lower tiers of tech are highly detailed and optimized. You won't feel like anything is missing until you get to the end game content.\n\nIf you liked Modded Minecraft, Space Engineers, Terraria or Factorio, FortressCraft is going to consume your life for about 5 days. Make sure to book time off work and make peace with your loved ones before you start playing.

reviewText:
put factorio and starforge in minecraft, and you get this game. Obnoxiously large world, vast, HUGE expances of caves, like Hang Son Doong big. Think it's just night because you can't see the cieling big. Recreate Dwarven cities big. This game revitalized that sence of wonder, being overwhelmed, and exploration that the first time I played minecraft did. Those that like Minecraft, and are a little done playing modpack after modpack and geeting burned out on it should DEFINENTLY play this game. and come on, it's only $13 (on 2/15/2016), why WOULDN'T you get this game?

I must say though, that if your computer is a toaster, it'll get frustrating with the game turning into a slide-show. This game isn't exactly friendly on your ram or proccessing capabilities, but you can drop the detail and graphics WAY down and still have a good time, it'll just look like it was done on the N64. But, normally this game is gorgeous, provided you have the computer to handle it.

For those of you who are experienced in minecraft (particularly tech mods) you'll discover that you will be making LOTS of controll based mistakes. Also, you'll have a decent understanding of tech progression, however, it is dificult to know ahead of time what you need to do. I would recomend that you play a few worlds to better understand what to do, and what way you prefer the most to do it. Your first few worlds are likely to fail in your eyes, this is fine, and fixable at just about any time, but you can always start fresh.

I would like to see a more comprehensive creative mode, as it does not lend to helping you actually mess around with logistical ideas, and what not, which I would like to see. currently, if you have an idea to use a system, you have to just try it out, which makes experimentation a potentially costly endeavour.

The short version is that this game is amazing, and any fan of starforge, minecraft, and/or factorio should most deffinently fork over the cash and get this game. it's not even all that much cash in the first place.

reviewText:
First thing: This is an early access game, things won't be 100% polished. In the state it currently is, it's extremely addicting and fun to play. You could spend 200+ hours even in it's current state and enjoy every minute.

The developer, a single person, continually releases patches on bleeding edge. I'm in the beta (which is a step higher) and even there you get a lot of nice updates still. The core version won't tend to see updates often, so i recommend opting into beta.

Onto the review!

There is so much potential for this game. If you like minecraft but sucked at building and making things look nice, or like playing with redstone, then you'll love this game without a doubt. It also makes buidling a breeze with the ability to place an entire row of blocks in a single click. I don't usually go out and buy games, espically if I've never head of it. But after watching video's of it for a bit I really became interested. And man it's the best game under $15 i've ever bought. You won't find much of multiplayer quite yet (it's still somewhat of a wip) but there is so much to do even so. The future of this game will only get better.

Even if it's current state was it's final state, I wouldn't feel like I wasted my money. So come join, support this game, tell your friends and your free time will never be used for anything else again.

reviewText: Used to play FortressCraft Chapter 1 on Xbox Live and loved that game. I am so glad I can play this on Steam! I can spend hours and hours just building random things. I made a world once where I just blew things up (FUN! i know!). On Xbox the game had a limit you can dig. However, on this game I've dug so much that it could not load in time and had to wait. HAHA\n\nMy two most favorite features are the creative mode and workshops. I'm not a survival type gamer, I do love to create. The creative mode is the reason I love it so much, I'm not into crafting I think that's too much work just to create something. Gotta love unlimited blocks. The workshop feature just extends the already limitless possibilites. Great game, I highly recommend it for players who love building with blocks! Word to the devs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I could never seem to get into Minecraft.  It always felt dull to me.  Trust me, I've tried quite a few times and friends have gone as far as letting me use their accounts to try and get a good full few days worth in it.

Nope, still didn't like it.  I was suggested to try some mods.  Now maybe it's just me, but if I need to also download some mods to make a game a little more enjoyable, it's already lost me.

Now FortressCraft Evolved, considering I never really understood how I could like these types of games really caught my eye firstly by it's price.  I think the price is too low.  Then by the quality and the world.  I can't fully compare Minecraft to FCE but considering FCE caught me instantly and i played 9 hours the first day straightw, I'd say that says something.

Not to mention the lighting effects are beautiful.  For it's price, it's a steal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL DR Section
The game probably should have not been released as early access in current state. Enemies were not implemented yet, instructions are far from appropriate… If you bear this in mind, you are ford of creative mode and in survival you tolerate many aspects missing, you can like it. Otherwise give it another year and return then for better game.

Detailed Section
Creative mode

I tested only few minutes to get achievements, it seemed to work, but i tis not my cup of tea so for feedback on that check other reviews.

Survival mode

This was the part I bought the game for and put full day of play in. The name „Fortresscraft“ evoked in me that I will face enemies and build fortress to repel them… well, no. Enemies are not implemented yet and so this part of game does not exist.

The survival in current game is about energy - how you prevent to lose it and how you handle when you on zero not to freeze/burn/die from falling damage, nothing more and nothing less. So far I play my first play and have not died once because I am cautious (although I twice did mistake nearly costing me life).

Information / Tutorial

On start you have few pages to read – and frankly, who wants to read so much text? Afterwards, although there is nice feature of research of everything, it is not used to serve information in nice small relevant packets. What a shame.
I fear that this part was heavily underestimated with regards of „early access“ – and by that discouraging many new players not able to absorb the game system.

Movement

Game gives player very powerful tool – grappling hook. It seems to me that easiness of movement around is dependent on mastery of this helpful companion. It allows quick ascending, but also horizontal movement.
And for moving down there is falling… 20 blocks of fall being ok was something I had trouble with in the beginning, but then I got used to it and started to make my digging to use this as advantage.
Summary: if you will make ways minecraft way, you will spend a lot of time makong stairs where they are not needed and simple shaft-mining is more rewarding.

Resources / Automation

Game has two types of resources – blocks and ores- Blocks are rapidly mined by hand. There are many types of blocks but sadly with nearly no difference – why is there hewn stone, stone and deep stone is quite a question for me (it is not even to mark depth, as for that you have your HUD. And why only hewn stone can be used as item for crafting is again very questionable.

Ores are mined through mining devices – and are probably intended for core concept of automation (so you build way to provide them with fuel or raw energy and to bring what they dug back). But that is simply not working for me and is demotivating by fact that the ore vein is depletable so what I build will stop to work sooner or later. Also smelting the ore in smelter is example of punishing mechanism – if you do not set it right and provide not enough energy, all will be wasted on failed attempt to heat it up with no real smelting in the end.

Summary

Although my comments are showing mainly negative aspects of current state of the game, I believe it has potential and as it is in early access, I give it positive result. Still, there is much to do and I believe that some of core concepts will need revision, especially when enemies will be added – they can change the game to be addictive… or not. I hope for the first.

reviewText:
Fortresscraft Evolved is a very orginal game indeed. Looking for a minecraft clone? Then you're not going to find one here. After many years of running modded minecraft servers, I was quite sick to the back teeth of the game. That being said, I did get this game thinking there would be some similarities and expected to get bored very quickly. This game, quite simply put, is amazing. The developer is nothing short of a genius!

The game has you start with afew supplies, after crash landing on an Alien planet. You are given a small tutorial, and then thrown into the deep end. At this point, I went and watched a few episodes of Direwolf20's lets plays. After being educated a little.. I jumped back into the game.

You begin by scanning for various ores, and setting up mining equipment. While this is happening you will be also scanning new blocks and plantlife. This accumulates research points which you can use to unlock new research projects and equipment.

It's not long past this point, you realise that 5 hours of game time has passed, and you've simply got lost in this enormous game! By this point I had found my first 4 ore types, and had begun building a system of convayors that could fill my smelters on the surface. Research seemed very simple at first.. but another few hours in and I was now constructing a lab and researching new projects was taking several hours at a time. This was ok though because I had so much other stuff to do while this was happening.

However.. the bigger your base becomes, the more power you use.. the higher your base threat becomes.. and it's not long before you threat analyser is telling you.. Attack immanent!". Now for those like me who love the tech
date: and the factory side of the game.. the invading alien swarms will only attack your central hub.. and once it's health is 0
recommended: it just reboots. That is unless you're playing hardcore.. and then its game over.\n\nSo as I went deeper into the ground
hoursPlayed: I realised just how big this game was. Some of the caves
voteText: from top to bottom
helpfulPercent: were bigger than minecraft
votesHelpful: bedrock to sky... I would liturally hold my breathe incase I fell off a ledge
votesTotal: as death meant I would drop all my equipment. So far i've been 1
votesFunny: 187 blocks deep.. and everytime I go exploring
commentsCount: I just can't explain the feeling of being so small
column16: in caves so large..\n\nThis game is great for those wanting some survival
column17: some tower defence
column18: and some tech. I love all the machines that automate the ore collecting and the minecarts that collect the ores.. the way the power system works
column19: and the defending of my base. It really is very well balanced... and it has just the right difficulty level to keep most playing
column20: and not getting bored.\n\n10/10"
column21: February 2

reviewText:
So I have only played a few hours in enough to get near the end game content. There is plenty to be said for this game.

I have heard people consistently compare it to factorio (which i have never played nor minecraft). its got a pretty steep learning curve but there is a pretty decently fleshed out ingame help manual albeit it still doesnt help you in first learning. Best thing to do is watch the streans of youtube videos on this before you play!

One of the games more creative solutions is a game option to let the system adjust graphic options based on a framerate you set. This can be annoying at times but it works fairly well in keeping the game running smoothly which is especially useful for older machines.

The research and semi tower defense is prob what set this game apart the most.

reviewText:
FortressCraft Evolved, Is a remarkable blend of mechanics coupled together in awesomeness. Its like Factorio and a VERY tech heavy MODDED Minecraft had a baby together but didnt want it, so along came DjArcas and he raised and nurtured this creation into something magnificent......... and he's still making it! He is accepting feedback and development ideas from his discord channel and his twitch streams, I dont know many folks that do this, even in this day and age!

Well, the shear magnitude of the game world is breath taking, finding a cavern throwing a glowstick and watching this fall without hitting the bottom, makes your stomach backflip and try to climb out of your mouth, meanwhile trying to navigate and plan routes for conveyors is merely one of several things that you will end up happily wasting several hours and more than one occassion!

The progression is fantastic, the way it gets your mind thinking of ways to automate or improve a system.

All in all, this is a beautiful game that has more than enough in content for the price as it stands and there is only more to come!!

reviewText:
I was a sceptic of this game at first. (Thought it would be a minecraft clone. Btw. its not its got the voxles and yes they remind one of minecraft, yes you mine but thats about as close to minecraft as it gets ) then  I decided eh why not its deciently priced for a game ill give it a go. I honestly didnt think i would like this game now im hooked i Dont notice what time it is till its waaaay past the time i need to get off. it is a lil slow in the beginning but once you start getting conveyer belts going you cant stop.

So I crash land first time nooo idea what I'm doing. scan some blocks research some stuff find some ore. make trips back and forth to charge power and get ores. thought this is tedious make some belts n laser power no more trips. look for more ores.... WTF im under attack by what ... ooooo i made the wasps mad. set up turrets go back lookin for more ores. died died died some more. ooooo im to cold down here make better gear go deeper. ... how'd i die that time ... oooo toxic fumes..... make more gear go deeper. build lots and lots of more goodies. go exploreing ..... wth almost craped my self when i ran into a giant worm spittin acid.  more turrets ( feels safer .... )


Honestly i could go on and on but theres so much to build / explore n do in this game it would take a long time to explain it all. but if you enjoy crafting / survival / builder games with logistics n factory line setups i would suggest this for you its waaaaaayyyyyyy better than minecraft it just has blocky voxels that look waaaay better than minecrafts anyway.

reviewText:
Really amazing game, with a very active developer :D I can recommend getting this, and even the DLC to support this amazing game!

Game has mod support, which is being improved as time goes on. Quite easy to mod the game to your own liking, if unsatisfied with the balancing of the game.

After 500 hours, the game is still offering new challenges, with the newly redo of the Hard Mobs difficulty, whole new challenges appears.

The new Casual mode offers a great alternative for those who might not have unlimited time to play the game, with a little boost to early game infrastructure as well! :D

Community is very helpful, and the modding community as well.

Having completed the game a few times, on different difficulties, I believe the game still have more to offer for me, as there are still machines that I havn't played around with. As well as a major rebalance that I havnt tried myself yet either.

A lot of hours for a silly low amount of money. Insanity!

Also one of the only games, that I have played, which have enough content and still isn't repetitive, that I have actually been able to stream it.

Thumps up from me.

reviewText:
This is not an easy game to review.  And I am not a reviewer.

But I love this game.

Yet I realise it will NOT please the masses.

Although you can play slightly faster modes, the default mode (that I'm playing on) is quite slow. (at start at least).

You get to explore as in Minecraft... yet the surface world" is not pretty and a lot less varied.  There's nothign to do on the surface anyway.  It's a desolated planet. (I do not see this as a problem... I'm just stating that the "exploration" part is not as fun as in Mineraft... no sense of wonder as of "what am I going to find !!!???" since the answer is simple : snow and mountains.)

But there are stuff to find and explore carefully under the surface.

And then there is the logistic part.  [I'M NOT USING THE WORD "CONSTRUCTION"
date: BUT "LOGISTIC"].  You want to build a logistic network to make mineral extraction
recommended:
transport and transformation 100% automatic.

This is fun.

This is slow.

Specially at start.

There are means to make it faster when you create the world (accelerated modes where receipes are simpler).  But the default mode
hoursPlayed: per exemple
voteText: require 8 Copper ore to make 1 copper bar.   But the mining-machine extracts 1 ore every 22 seconds
helpfulPercent: costs a LOT of mineral to build
votesHelpful:
and requires power that will cost a lot of materials as well.  You will be manually feeding your extractor for quite a long while.

But I don't mind as much as I though I would.

Each time you manage to make something 100% automatic and manage to double the speed of a process.... you'Re proud of it !

You should eventually be able to have something massive and super-productive.  AND THAT IS AWESOME.  It's rewarding.  It feels great.  Specially when you start from such ♥♥♥♥♥♥ installations.

progression is also getting faster.  Satisfactory.

reviewText:
A must have for fans of modded Minecraft and Factorio.

Automation from the ground up is aim of this game, so it's good to see a game like this, in it's current state, with the vast array of machines and upgrades it's possible to get. And it's blatantly clear how much there is for the developer to add, this is a game that you will spend well over two days (not two days in real life, but 48 hours in game) on now, come back and lose even more time later, with a bunch of new content.

While the tutorial maybe boring and dull, leading you through utter basics, the game features a world gen that is awe insipiring, with canyons carving scars in the terrain and caves seemingly without a bottom. Not to mention a literally infinite world.

A gem that I might have otherwise over-looked.

reviewText:
I am addicted to this game at the time i wrote this review, while the game is still in development i reccomend getting it. Basically this game is what you get when you mix Minecraft, a few of it's more technecal mods like Industrialcraft and Buildcraft and turn it into a full blown game. If you're a fan of Minecraft with those two mods then you should definitely play this, if you're a fan of voxel games in general i also think this is worth a try.

When you start off you're about to dock at a space station in the middle of a meteor shower when it's hit by an asteroid and you come crashing down to the planet below because of that. At the moment your goal is to build up a base, research the local enviroment for things you can use and send some power in orbit so your buddies in orbit can get the damaged station running. While you're doing this you have to defend yourself from the local wildlife and trying to prevent the illusive hive mind from spreading and destroying any clump of resin you find on your travels as these will give you useful rewards.


Let's start off with the bad:

- The game is still quite buggy and unstable (when i wrote the review) and multiplayer is even more unstable. Running the game at a graphic quality setting higher than good will almost guarantee your game will crash if not your computer at the moment.

- Enemies are quite buggy, going through blocks and if they die while inside of a block they could end up breaking the block they're inside.

- The game punishes you if you mine ores yourself as you barely get any ore out of veins which forces you to rely on your trusty ore extractors.

- This game is fairly hands off especially late game.

- The game is also quite CPU heavy, if your computer has a weak processor i'd say either upgrade or avoid this game until you do get an upgrade.


Now the good:

+ The worlds are randomly generated which can be good especially if you get a good seed with loads of bigger ore veins. You can even change a few settings in relation to the map such as how common ore is, how fast conveyors move items about and how strong the enemies are and so on.

+ While the progression has a few places that can be improved i think the devs have more or less nailed it.

+ There are a set of upgrades for your suit, your floating bot called Arthur and later on the massive spiderbot that helps you defend your base.

+ Automation is fun, especially when you get all four of the starter ores and you can build a basic power grid with coal generators, batteries to store energy and lasers to transfer energy from your generators to your extractors, turrets, even your forward outposts which you will need later on as you go deeper into the planet.

+ This game is so much better with friends, although you can only play cooperatively at the moment as everyone shares the same base but you do all have your own inventories.

+ The devs are very active, they try to push a patch out every month and sooner if the game has a massive problem. Every now and then they'll even throw in a feature that someone has suggested, complete with an achievement if you do use something a community member has suggested.

+ The game has a creative mode which has been massively improved upon from the original Xbox 360 game, even the detail blocks have come over from there.

+ If you have a massive problem with your game or computer there's a neat little system which aims to lower the chance your world will break as a result.

+ Research is interesting especially when you get the lab, you scan the local enviroment and analize those scans to find out what they are and get a few research points for your efforts which you spend on new recipes and early on new technologies. When you research a new technology you'll either get something useful or a new technology which can give you something useful.

+ On the technical side (at least i've heard) FortressCraft is one of those few games that makes good use of all your CPU cores no matter what so if you have a CPU with loads of weaker cores so if your machine doesn't have a CPU with a set of fewer, stronger cores then you might be in luck. This can be good news especially for AMD people as AMD CPUs (as far as i know) tend to boast a higher CPU core count compared to Intel CPUs of a comparable model.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

this game may not be entirely feature complete yet, and doesnt have a clear goal, but seeing it is in active development with competent, friendly and skilled developers, i see no reason not to love this game.
it is currently a sandbox creative with a sandboxy survival modes game, soon to be a game with creative and a true survival game mode with creepy crawlies...

it has similarities to minecraft, sure, and no doubt people will compare the two games to each other, but it is different on a multitude of levels and scale, and in a lot of areas.
i leave it up to you, the new player to find out what exactly, as i found that some players find different areas overlapping then others...


as for what is actually in the game, it works for the majority and is good fun, though not to much is there yet, but if it doesnt work (properly) it is highly likely that there is work being done on the subject which fixes or improves it the next or coming update(s), and if you report a bug which hasnt been covered properly yet, the devolopers will be very happy to fix or at least as soon as they can, and they let people know what they actually do.
you'll likely get a response anyway unless its considered trolling.

there are currently big feature updates on the roadmap to diversify the game and improve it as far as i know, which will make this game from a good alpha/beta, to great up till amazing released game. (*cough* *transportation* *cough* *fluids* *cough* *to name a few* *cough* *cough*)


i'd say if you like voxel based games, give this a try, its different from the norm with its machines and ideas, definatly worth the few bucks/euros it will cost you, though i have to warn you, there are bug, but this is normal for a young game (currently alpha/beta).
i paid, and i dont regret it a single bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now we can blow stuff up in this game.  Everything else is good as well.  Not quite sure what else to write here, so here's a recipe for homemade napalm:

Fill a large container about half-way with gasoline (diesel works best).
Take a Styrofoam plate and break it into small pieces.
Add the pieces to the gasoline mixture.

The gasoline will dissolve the Styrofoam into a jelly-like substance. Pour out the extra gasoline leaving the white, jelly-like substance – this is your napalm, which when lit, will burn for several minutes. Engine oil can be added to to the mixture to reduce (slow) the burn time of the substance.

Thank you for your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is not enough words to describe how AWSOME this game is even in early alpha state. There is no real combat (yet) but the single player survival mode is so damn fun i literaly stoped playing the MC(minecraft) ftb server i spent months setting up for this game. If you are a voxel/sandbox/survival fan of any sort or even if you are familiar with the concept i highly recommend this game it is worth every cent and then some.It is like a Fortresscraft original and MC modpacks had a baby and shot it up with steroids and it is only alpha the finished release will be godly compared to any sandbox type to date. The greatest thing about this game is the tech/research/automation system they have going on it is complex but at the time simple to understand the basics and i love the challange of the different enviromental hazards you have to counter
cold/heat so far have not come across any other types but the bases for other hazards are already implemented. So support this game if you read this review and like the sound of the game I know i will continue to support it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

yes, yes, yes - it looks like minecraft at first glance, now get over it fanboys...

...because even if it looks similar, it's very different!

I really enjoyed this game from the start. I never tried the creative mode, but i am heavy into the survival part and i think it's on the right path. Sure it is an alpha, so you will encounter some issues. But overall it looks and plays very promising.
I especially like the devs since they listen to the community, are active on the forums and quick to bring out new content, fixing bugs or just having a chat with you on the different topics.

Listen up folks, imo this is a no brainer for the sale price!!

i especially like:

+ the whole automation system
+ energy generation and distribution
+ future themed (yes, lazors!)
+ exploration and research
+ heavy machinery

reviewText:
FortressCraft Evolved is definitely a game that can absorb a lot of your time because of how expansive and intricate it is.  And that's a good thing!  I find myself constantly experimenting, changing, and iterating my systems to take advantage of new tech or just to maximize efficiency.  As of this writing, I have 200+ hours in game and I plan to at least tripple that.

At first glance, it might look like Minecraft or Factorio.  But this game is much more than that and really isn't comparable.  This game rewards efficient, scalable design, not one-off systems.  You can do many things by hand, but eventually, everything must become automated.  And that is a good way to understand the game.  You must automate everything.

For the price, this game is definitely worth it.  I've spent more on games that I've played less.  Additionally, the planned expansions sound exciting and definitely something I will want to play.

My recommendation: if you like designing or building systems, this game is a must-have.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed the time I've been playing this game.  The mechanics are quite simple but the interactions among them create a rich sandbox environment.

Some of the recent videos posted emphasize how extensive the caverns can be.  It's not an exaggeration.  The world is immense and the 3 dimensional aspect of the game is absolutely integral.  And advanced base can easily be to scale a few hundreds meters across and a thousand meters tall (or deep may be more accurate).

The developer is extremely active in the community and is constantly adding new things to the game.

I strongly recommend the game.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The bad reviews for this game are unfortunate, because I've enjoyed many hours of play.  Fortresscraft Evolved has a lot of features I like in a game and has kept me attached to my computer screen for way longer than my girlfriend would like.  “Yeah, cutie, I’ll be to bed soon.”  But that never happens.  One recent (and ridiculously long) negative poster had 801+ hours of play!  He must have enjoyed the game much more than he admits and definitely got his money’s worth!
On a side note first: I did not get this game for free, am not being paid to post a positive comment, and aren't using some fake account to skew the reviews.
So for the TL:DR portion of my rant....
I'd like to rebuttal some arguments about the game as to prevent misconceptions.
The game is a complete, but open ended, fully playable game, and is constantly being updated with more features added and patch fixes for minor glitches.  If there are resources with descriptions like not implemented yet" or "has no use yet
recommended: it’s because that is a new feature only recently added to the already expansive game!  Anyone complaining (IMHO) about the game not being complete
hoursPlayed: is really only complaining that the developer refuses to stop adding more and more features to the game!  And how is that a valid complaint?!  If you think you’re going to jump into a new game
voteText: play for a bit
helpfulPercent: with the sole intent on “beating” it
votesHelpful: you’re looking at the wrong game.  I’m sure one day there may be an end-game
votesTotal: like Mojang added to Minecraft much later after release.  But for now
votesFunny: feel at ease about spending your hard earned cash on this title. (which is cheap in comparison to much lesser games) Watch some videos.  Learn some strategies.  And enjoy the open ended-ness of the gameplay in its current high-content state.\nI’m looking forward to the upcoming Frozen Factory and Magma Core expansions and am fully willing to buy those as a DLC if that’s the way the dev chooses to go
commentsCount: because I’ve already gotten way beyond my money’s worth with the way the game is now.  Cheersies\n- "Don't push the button anymore

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game seems to get a lot of crap from other players, and I see what they see. However, with a little time, reading, and work I actually started to have fun playing this game. The confusing interfaces, controls, and something else about the general feel of the game is outputting, and when I first launched it, within 10 minutes I slammed the book shut and stored it on a high shelf. But I gave it a second chance, this time more open hearted. The game is playable and fun, you get to mine, use the resources, build machines, and expand. You just need a guide to do so. The interfaces? Very counter-intuitive and inconsistant. Overall the game is rather well done, has room for improvement, uses a great concept I'd love to see more of in gaming (automation of resource refinement), but just has some painfully rough edges. If the developer(s?) would devote one long, productive day solely to interface enhancement and a bit of easier to understand starter stuff, then the game would feel a lot better. Also, remember, this is early access! It definitely feels it deserves this flag, and I hope it can fix these issues. If so, this game can definitely be something great in my library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to recommend this game, but I can't.  Writing this review, I can't decide if I should recommend it or not.

Pros:

-Voxel is always fun.
-Building tools allow building large structures without much work.
-Developers seem to care about their players, replying to reviews and all.
-A TON of blocks. Even dozens dedicated to building lunar and space stuff.
---------------

Cons:

-More demanding than most voxel games, due to shaders.
-Some things just don't fit in (e.g. the weather staff's mesh that controls weather is nice and smooth, but it's a voxel game.
-Annoying robot flies around telling you what block you have in your hand.
------------------------

I know that this game is early access, so I know it'll all get better.  This review is based on my personal opinion.

reviewText:
If you like modded minecraft (with tech mods) or factorio then this game is definitely for you, It takes that concept of industrialization, automation, and tech progression and builds on it massively. Not only that, but It also adds some actual threats for you to deal with (we all know that minecraft mobs aren't a threat at all unless you specifically go looking for a challenge) and adds a bunch of cool QOL features like a grappling hook and better building mechanics that improve the experience a whole lot.

Yes, as some other reviews have pointed out this game does have its issues, like inconsistent inventory management and sub-par UI, BUT, I think that all of the benefits greatly out-weigh these quirks and result in a very enjoyable experience.

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: My primary reasons for enjoying this game are that unlike modded minecraft, this game was designed from the ground up to support these complexities. As such, you can create large numbers of machines (with animations) working in one area without the performance issues minecraft encouters. Also, the multi-tiered ore system is enjoyable, with different environmental hazards at different levels making digging deeper interesting.\n\nThe downsides I find with this game are primarily in its aesthetic. There are no biomes excepting the default snow/hill template. This makes the surface world uninteresting to explore. Also, the lighting effects need some tweaking as they reflect off of machines/conveyors in odd ways and make playing the game at night, or attempting to make the factory indoors less enjoyable.

reviewText:
Epic game.  Quite feature-rich and playable, while still being in active (and community engaged) development, yet designed with the innate desire (I would say promise, if this wasn't the world of software with its ever-emergent unknowable bugs) that its development will never force a world reset.  The dev is on the forums almost daily, actively engaging with users re: feature tweak/addition suggestions, bug reports, balancing issues... rather than buying a buggy in-development game and getting cryptic or dismissive responses to your suggestions/issues from the obvious PR arm of things (as opposed to the techies who know what the bleep you're talking about), you're buying Minecraft-esque access to a living, /thriving/ beta version, with much less endemic issues than Minecraft, ALONG WITH front-row tickets to real-life large-scale game development unfolding in front of your eyes.

And, it is incredibly well-optimized when it comes to visual/computing-resource playability.  My favorite feature of the game, far and away, is found not in the gameplay, but in the settings menu: click a checkbox, set your target framerate, and the game will take ahold of the quality and render distance settings in order to keep you achieving that.  In a frenetic base with umpteen-gazillion things going on, it'll automatically turn down shadows and maybe kill the render distance - just like our IRL brains would tend to focus on a small subset of the goings-on in a real hectic factory - while during landscape exploration, you can get the voxel equivalent of Skyrim's brilliant vistas.  (Hint to DJ: World-gen structures of awesomeness maybe?)

Geeky stuff aside, the gameplay... wait, never mind about geeky stuff aside."  If you just want another alien shoot-em-up with resource management and base-building mechanics in the tactical background

reviewText:
An amazing game!!

I have put a lot of time in the last few months into this game and keep coming back to it almost daily to try new strategies and to see what dev has added to the game (which is done almost daily).   I have never personally experienced a game that had such an open forum for the development of a game.  As a long time game player from games back to Everquest, WoW, Minecraft, etc (and even back to the days of Zork and before) I can't remember ever having the opportunity to give feedback on something and have it actually become a part of the game.   (Don't expect every idea you come up with to be implemented, but if you have a well reasoned and thought out idea you stand a shot).

Fortresscraft takes some work.  If you are looking for a game you just start up and have it hold your hand all day while you mindlessly hit a few keys, then this might not be the game for you.   But if you like a challenge and are looking for a game that is constantly evolving and growing, a communitity of players who will help you if you have questions, and a game where you can go online and watch the developer streaming as he builds new game content then you may want to consider this.

I am addicted to the game and although I have a lot of hours of play time I am nowhere near completing it.   Like the old saying goes, it isn't about the destination
date: it is about the journey".   The journey of playing Fortresscraft Evolved for me has been a blast.   I only wish every game I had ever purchased had given me so many hours of fun and enjoyment."

What is FortressCraft Evolved?
There are two modes: Creative and Survival. Creative is the same as any other generic Minecraft clone. Survival is a bit more interesting
votesTotal: and it's where I spent most of my hours in-game. The premise of the Survival mode is a mix between Factorio and Minecraft

There are "plans" to include enemies/combat to give a bit more of a challenge for players who don't just want to mine. Right now exploration isn't that fun. It's a fairly bleak surface world with repetitive caverns below.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in early alpha and might be a lot of fun, when it is completed.
At the moment however, it lacks the simple design of its predecessors (i.e. Minecraft?) which left me cursing several times.

It all starts with a rather buggy menu - there is a small camera driven animation which hovers in front of several signs.
...which - unlike any current games - do not light up when the mouse hovers over them.
Getting into a single player mission is even worse because you have to click the empty space in the middle of the screen (no text or anything like that to actually tell you to do so).
When creating a world, the dialogs appear unresponsive. (you click the button - wait for a second or two, click again, ... until you are thrown into the world)

In game there are some nice mechanics, namely the survival against the wild system. (your suit keeps you warm on a frozen planet and if its power is fully depleted, you die after a short time).
But in my opinion, this is one of the biggest flaws at the moment:
There is a brutal world out there, trying to kill you and you have to fight it from the very beginning - without much help or direction from the game.
While several games have recently tried this do what you like and see what comes of it!"-approach
date: this game has you fighting for your life from the very first moment and thereby hinders any attempt at  a shallow start (again
recommended: think Minecraft: hacking away at those mud-cubes
hoursPlayed: only to find out they're almost worthless - but you didn't die from that and could switch over to actually mining something useful)\n\nHowever
voteText:
there are too many unexplained phenomenons to actually rush into this game without any knowledge.
After reading a few guides it might start to make sense that you should simply search for coal to power your equipment - but if you've yet to read those guides you might spend the first attempt at survival cursing.
Simply because you start with several fancy technologies in your inventory and can't place them or know what to do with them in the first place.
Then there is the awkward mining process - it feels counterintuitive having to repeatedly press the mouse button to mine. (why can't I keep it pressed like in Minecraft and it simply keeps mining?)

I'd say its got potential once several flaws are fixed.
But at the moment there are simply too little hints to actually get started and enjoy the game without reading several guides."

Once finished,I can see it being an amazing place to spend most of your time.
