reviewText:
As it is now, I can't reccomend this game. It's hard even on the 'easy' settings to do anything really. With the combonation of heat/cold, energy storage of your suit only one begginer smelter and a whole lot of things early game take way too long! It is a time sink that is in my opinion far worse than other 'builder' games. I will compare to one that most everyone should know: Minecraft.

Comparing Minecraft to Fortresscraft
*You can easily build multiple smelters right from the start really/ Fortresscraft you may finally unlock a basic smelter after a few hours play.

*Ores are generally spawned with more of a pattern/ Fortresscraft is more luck based. Meaning it may take a few hours to even build the basics.

*You already know all crafting, you just need the proper tool/ Fortresscraft you need to scan almost everything, and research it. Use the researcher to gain building rights. Making the beginning game so long and tedious.

These are just a few issues I have.

One could argue: Recode the recipes in the data files. I shouldn't have to. One could say use creative mode. Then I lose out on needing anything and lose on battling enemies. Plus you don't get all the energy stuff or anything. Or none that I could see.

I wish there was a kind of hybrid creative/ survival mode. Kind of like how you can switch between the modes in Minecraft with commands. And the creative mode in Fortresscraft had ALL the blocks plus being able to battle enemies should you choose to.

So unless you have hours to sit down and figure this game out, don't expect anything to be built quickly. As it is, I can't reccomend it. Maybe it's not for me since I don't have hours and hours to sink into it to find everything and such. Which is why I like Minecraft better. If you want something that does similar to this but qucker, Try Factorio. You can even cheat if you wish, and I don't feel cheating ruined the game for me on that as I still do a lot.

It has potential. I love the idea of having a factory with belts/ transporters, and building a defensive base and all that. So I WILL check in on this game from time to time as I do like the ideas. It just needs to be a little more open I guess you could say. Allow us to do what we want, if we wish to speed things up some allow commands to do so or something. I'll keep watching it for updates and such and may update my review at a later date.

reviewText: Starting out can be rough, depending on your world. I tried a couple before I found one I was happy with. It will take time.The game is heavily based around automation, so you can continue to dig deeper and find new things, then automate those new things to get it all back to your base. At first, you will have to babysit things. You simply don't have the resources to get things rolling on their own for the first hour, maybe two. Watch a couple of videos on it. You'll see how others do things, you'll get a good understanding of the basics, and you'll have some ideas as to how to set your own system up. It takes a lot of time to really get a lot going on, but if building up to that isn't your cup of tea, then I might advise a different game type. There are several more mechanics at play here than in MineCraft, and pretty much any other game in this vein. It takes a lot of the concepts explored in Space Engineers, removes space, and instead focuses on mining materials and setting them up to work for you.

reviewText:
Simply AWESOME!

Warning: This game will suck up a lot of your time so prepare to have your rear end planted firmly in your seat... worth every minute though.

I have read it's a clone of Minecraft... uhm, sure, if an Orange is a clone of an Apple. Mods make Minecraft what it is, and this game already has amazing content without mods.

If you are into machines, automation, logistics and a 'never ending' world (there's no bottom like bedrock in MC... it just keeps going!), superb graphics, regular new content and a development team that has your constructive input and interests at heart (within reason of course)... then this game is for you.

There's even a development live stream where bugs are fixed, content added, input considered, questions answered and... a cat?!!! Who else does that!?  :-D

reviewText:
TL;DWTR:

It has a steep learning curve.
It is a challenge.
It is a factory game.
You get attacked.
You try to endgame.
You try to endgame again.

If you love slow paced 'crafting/automation' games (like Factorio, but not 1 hour and you're done), with a sense of acheivement when you build that massive (3 dimensional) factory that does exactly what you ask, while you are being attacked, and trying to grow your factory, so you can be attacked more while you try to endgame, then you will very much love this game.
It starts slow, and has a steep learning curve, but players who can bear to not have their hands held, will love it.

NTL;WTR:

I love the Battlefield series of games.
I love getting into a fresh round of fast paced action.
I love killing those 4 blokes who all came up the elevator at Siege of Shanghai C.
And most of all, I hate the fact that players who have all played the game a long time and acquired knowledge and experience in the game think it is their right to Always be on the winning team". Where is the challenge in fighting a bunch of noobies that don't know what they are doing? Where is the fun without a challenge?

FortressCraft Evolved is nothing like Battlefield
date:
thank goodness.
There is no teamstacking. There is no "How the f did he get me". But it is a challenge. And it is fun.

I've only owned it for a little bit. And when I first started playing it
recommended: I wasn't sure what I was doing
hoursPlayed: and not much has changed for newbies. Spend a week on making a proper tutorial for new players

reviewText: I've had this game for about a year or two, yet I never really put a lot of time into it. The first 15-hour playthrouh I had was boring, dull, had little content, and progress was unrewarding. Now, what playtime i have that makes up the rest, I have had a lot of fun. Progress has a much more rewarding feeling to it, setting up automation and watching something automatically complete itself (Which before needed you to move seperate parts all over) it the best. Exploring this game on my own, with little to no help from outside (other than asking wikipedia how much power a solar generator makes) is one of the most fun things I have done in quite a while. When I found out there was actually some degree of threat found in the wasps, I was amazed. My first playthrough had these little robots floating around occasionally, but nothing like the threats I have seen here. I'm not even mid-game and I still enjoy the slow process of manually carrying ores to the surface, because I know that these ores are going to be turned into bars, which will be turned into circuits and plates, which will be turned into research pods, which will be used to research automatic transportation methods for those ores I have been bringing up manually. When something comes full circle in this game, it is probably one of the most satisfying feelings. On a side note, the amount of fun I have had in this game is comparable to the fun i've had in Factorio.

reviewText:
so after a hiatus from FCE i've managed to rack up another 25 hours in the last 3 days, suffice it to say this game has improved signifigantly since i last played (around the time my first review was written)
my previous review was full of candor, i was only trying to point some the holes in the progression.

i would like to add, for anyone who had read my previous review ... i went into the game expecting a different game experience and it relfected that disappointment in my review.

in any case i was happily surprised when i started up a new world again. before the game was simply too easy, 1 million+ piece ore veins and no hostile mobs were my biggest issues. the tech tree progression is a lot smoother now and makes more sense.

Pros:
-extensive tech tree progression ( lots of new higher tier machines)
-survival is more apparent now
-unique mobs
-early game progression is much more balanced
-more building blocks added (windows and a few others)
-very few bugs/glitches ... reletively polished
-new base defense system .. awesome :)

Cons:
-still some unfinished UI elements, nothing gamebreaking
-no penalty for death
-still no compass or map feature of any kind  .. lost your base? easy, dieing is the fastest way to find your base :)
-the giant Spider bot like to step all over you a lot :P (doesn't affect gameplay but is annoying when trying to see something its standing on lol)

now knowing what to expect from FCE has been a better experience for myself, so if you resource/power management and logistics and really strange mobs trying to hinder your progess constantly then grab this game.

side note: the Developer seems to be a lone wolf on this game so dont' expect a lot of new content to be added on a schedule like other games. updates a little slower for this game but the dev is working his tail off to produce this game :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am so into this game! I've spent hundreds and hundreds of hours on Minecraft and I really wanted a game like it, and Fortresscraft Evolved brings a fresh dynamic to a play-style I already loved. It's a lot of fun to find and set up the ore sites and play around with machines and conveyor belts and lifts and funny robots. I'm excited to see the future content for crafting 'detail blocks' etc. I'd love to explore different environments and gather a greater variety of resources from them, such as types of wood, so I can pretty-up the areas that aren't industrial. I'd enjoy more enemies and friendly robots. I just can't wait to see more content and I can tell I'll be living in this game for quite a while!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Aside from looking like a potato crudly taped to a monkey with down syndrome, Fortresscraft has some good Ideas... but can the company use them in a way to complement the game?

Im gonna answer that right off the bat, no it can't. This game realeased in early access more than 4 YEARS AGO and I still have a better time playing the orignal one on the XBLA. This game completly fails to motavate you to do anything at all. It starts you out with a drill gun that can dig through ANYTHING IN THE GAME so I had no reason to craft a better one even if you can. It also starts you out with a ♥♥♥♥ING LASER CANNON so there is also no reason to get a better weapon either, y'know im not even sure if theres enemys in the game to shoot at. I did find little flying robot things that I could'nt collect like a perk (like in the first one) and I tried to shoot them with the Mega Death Death Ray Gun that it just gives you and it just wizzed right passed them. Speaking of robots you have a little robot thing that follows you around and shows you the block you're carrying incase your completly brain dead. Lastly, it spawns you with a 3 tourches  that emit enough heat to burn through the earths crust. See, there is this system much like thwe hunger in minecraft in here but with tempeture. And scince it spawns you in the middle of a blizzard I decided to make a house to get warm in. And after I made a house of wood and stone and waited for 5 minutes I did not get any warmer. So I dug in the middle of a moutain hoping to get warm and littarly nothing happened with 5 blocks of stone on either side protecting me from the cold. So the only way to get warm is by getting items that emit heat. But scince the crafting system is as easy to work as rubber stilts You're. Basicly. ♥♥♥♥ed. But when I was on the brink of freezing to death I decided to die in good lighting, so I set down a tourch and withing 12 seconds I overheated and died ... so ... ya.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i love this game, if you cant tell by the number of hours i have spent playing it.

to get first things first, the game has LOTS of room to expand.

Graphics:
good graphics, some glitches here and their, nothing game braking or making it impossible to play. lighting in caves is grate, not to bright that one light lights up everything in the cave, not to dim that 5 blocks away and you cant see anymore. however it will take more than one to find your way around in one of the large caves.

Sound:
nice sound effects, could use some tweeking. everything sounds the way it should, ie, snow sounds like snow, stone sounds like stone, metal has a nice ring to it(guess were wearing combat boots, or walking around in tap dancing shoes)
they recently added in a ankle cracking sound that makes my stumach turn every time i hear it, which is often since their are such large open area's.

Game play.
oh so much can be added here its not even funny, going to be long nights wondering what they will put in next. if your an avid explorer like me, the caves in this game will keep you busy(alittle empty atm, but that only means so much can be added, but still much area to look around, and get lost in, with your suit runing low on power). their are many of these kind of caves, so if your not getting lost in them thats your fault. I spent 4 hours looking one over(the last half hour was just getting back to where i entered the cave)

multi-player
it has only recently come out, so i don't have much to say on this.

more to come as game play expands :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I remember when I first encountered Minecraft on a fluke. I figured hmm, this looks like ♥♥♥♥ visually but the concept sounds good. Several hours later.... what just happened? Did the game combine a metric ton of fun and interesting core elements making it stupid" addictive... yep.

It'd been a long time. I figured I'd snatch this $9 game called FortressCraft Evolved while I was browsing other titles. That's well spent. Even in its current form there's a good amount to experiment with.

If you're impatient but also want to play survival you can modify some core xml files related to resources and a few other things. Mess around and enjoy.

If you like these types of games there's quite a few that suck ballz and aren't worth playing for free.

FortressCraft Evolved is one worth the current price. Time will tell as it "evolves" how much more it may be worth. Odds seem in its favor based on what I see in the content and its direction."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

where do i eve start? first the good points, it's basically miecraft with a built in tekkit mod, which i find to be amazing and if not better than both minecraft and the tekkit mod itself, why you ask? let me explain, FCE literally has infinite worlds, with no block height either, leaving the possibility to build things on a scale previously never seen in a voxel type game, there is a complete method to automate everything, which if like me you hate spending continuous hours digging and mining, is perfect, ad using tekkit as my example here, unlike tekkit where nothing is really self explanetary and you spend longer looking at a wiki page finding exactly what you need to build what in terms of resource and machine's, this gives you the basics, collect ore, smelt and craft and thats it, sure it's a pain locating said ore, but heh you get that in minecraft, the difference is i find an ore vien in MC and i get 10 ore from it, here you can get hundreds of thousands of ore before it is depleted thats a win. another plus is the fact it runs on unity... unity is great, it really is and it plays wonderfully on my low end laptop without any lag spikes, bugs or glitches, which is brilliant.

now, the bad points, (yes i understand it is early access and things take time) while there is a survival mode, there is nothing survival about it other than you can freeze to death which sure, is a cool mechanic, but easily avoidable, the ingame 'guide' feel's to be lacking in information, like whats the little icon next to the lamp icon? and what is the secondary battery? things like that could use some further explination, some of the textures are a little low quality and seem 'cheap' like basic model designs, the tool for example, the animation makes the whole think look like all the parts are just hovering there and aren't really connected to each other, but thats not exactly game breaking.

summery: basically this is a great game, while it lacks the features other games provide with mods, this has everything as stock, it runs brilliantly on even low end machines and i can only imagine what it loks like on a top end rig, as it is early access there are still plenty of things that can be improved on and added, which given how much i feel i get for this game paid £1.49 during a sale, is great, would i pay full price for this? as it stands sadly no i wouldnt, when more is added? certainly, at the time of review i have spent 8.2 hours game time having purchased it only two days ago, 10/10 will recommend

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If any game needs a wiki it's FortressCraft Evolved! This game seems to have so much potential and it's still in the early development stages. It's highly playable, even with the occasional bug or world glitch here and there.  I've played a good three hours and still have yet to explore this games full potential in it's current state. There's just so much to do!

If I had to pick one thing that bugs me a bit it's the asthetic to the game. It doesn't look the best. There are some odd colours and a number of the machines look a bit too quirky. Hopefully they will do some remodels and re-textures to make the machines and lands look more consistent with themselves. I'm sure the devs will!

All in all, if you like sandbox/survival games and you're looking to make sweet fortresses with working lifts that take you down into the depths of your world and much MUCH more, buy it. BUY IT NOW!

Love it.
voteText: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a well thought developer's dream of a building/exploration game in a voxel world that wants you to build a self sustaining mining-ish operation. I say mining-ish because your resources are 99% dug out of the ground, but this isn't just a dig and build kind of game. You need power to live, you get power through different means. One of these means that takes it away from just mining are things like solar energy and the ability to store the electricity in batteries. If you like a sandboc voxel game and the idea of building a self-sustaining operation this game is for you. There is also a creative mode, but I can't speak much on this because that is simply not my general area of interest. The early game has a very good push to make you want to expand and evolve. The energy requirement to keep you alive feels very real when the game starts and after about 30 minutes of keeping yourself alive I most certainly experienced the wanting to keep myself alive with less direct input and the only solution to this was building things to sustain themselves. I would say I have done about 50% of what can/could be accopmlished in an average scope of the game (not a 100% copmletionist have to get every achievement kind of view). One way I like to way games is how many good hours a got per dollar. Currently I have 65 hours and I believe I bought it at $10 (USD). That's 6.5 hours per dollar which is far above my threshold of a game that should be considered bad if you play it less than 1 hour per dollar. I definitely got hooked on this game and stayed up late hours wanting to keep playing.

One of the best things I can say for this game is the small development team. The developer is ALL OVER THE FORUM. The developer always wants more feedback and seems to spend all day speaking to players and improving the game. It gets updated constantly and has a well thought out road map of what is next.

I would say invest now. Get your money's worth and enjoy I great new take on a voxel game.

Also, I forgot it is moddable and the community will help with that.

TL;DR
It's a good game. (I don't give 0-10/10 because it is meaningless in a 1 paragraph review). This game is worth your money and has a great theme and support to become even greater.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far this game is pretty great considering it is still early access.

I haven't personally had any bugs or game crashes.  Game loads very quickly as well as the world generation or world loading as you move around.

At the time of writing this I'm 14 hours in and still haven't reached mid game.  I would guess even at the early access level of development there is at least 60 hours of entertainment to be found.

If you're a fan of minecraft you might like this game, if you're a fan of factorio or crafting / automating style of games you'll really enjoy it.

The only negatives at the moment I have is that there is no real threat in surivial mode death just spawns you back to your base, and mobs have not been added yet, but again, still in development and the games current status works well.  Also the progression to being able to do anything efficiently besides manual filling/unloading miners, hoppers, etc. is a little much.  I ended my last game session to finally being able to build my 2nd smelter, which is a bottle neck that limits progression more so then having a consistant progression of acomplishments.  But as i've said several times it is in beta so I'm sure as more mid game and end game things are added smelters will be more available early on.

Overall the game is great and quite entertaining.  $9 bucks for what I expect to be 30+ hours minimium of enjoyment is better then any cost to entertainment ratio I expect from most AAA games.  And once they start doing more patches I'm sure I'll get even more enjoyment out of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well this game seems to be better in the future, so I give it thumb-up. The game, however, is not really worth a thumb-up at the moment, because the game is not really playable now.

The developer says that the creative mode is easy to use, but I didn't see how 'easy' it is. Well if you have played Minecraft, and you like building, you should probably know the plugin WorldEdit, and that really make building easier. But although this game have a 'powerful' building tool, it can't really make any different. If I want to place a chunk, that's OK, but it's really a challenge to make the chunk in proper size and position. The 'powerful' building tool seems to be more like a terrain brush rather than an assistant tool. In my opinion, something that can be called building tool should at lease have all the function that WroldEdit have. And the build to me function didn't work at all.

By the way, there are no slopes, even no slabs and stairs in the game. Although I can make it an model manually, is that really easy that I need 8 models of one meterial in order to create the roof? And I REALLY want some furnitures but I can't find anything that really seems to be furniture, and I even can't find doors.

Also the survival mode is really hard to play. The ping tool in the scanner really fustrate me a lot, because it can make the screen bright violin and it's hard to see through with these on. Energy things is almost OK, but why can't power centre charge the research centre? Every time I have to move the energy cell right next to the research centre in order to charge it, and transfer energy manually.

And the UI is hard to use. Something that I really want to complain is that, could I have an inventory? And also, drag-drop control is not featured, and I should first select the item in my hot bar, and then open the UI to feed it, and the energy centre have no buffer, so I have to throw in a coal every minute, before I can have any automatic machanic.

So with all these problems, why I still give it thumb-up? The main reason is that I only get the game for 2.24USD (and I purchased 13.44CNY), that's far cheaper than Minecraft. And also you can't expect a lot on a game in technic preview stage. 4 years ago, I used to play the classic version of Minecraft, and that has even less function than this game in this stage, but everyone enjoy that. There's still a lot of time for this game to be improved, and I hope that my 2 USD will worth 40 USD in the future.

So, it's still worth to buy it, but don't expect too much too soon. Buy it and put it aside for several years is OK.

column23: and I really believe it has potential. It's not going to be the Minecraft killer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is still too Early Access (even for me - someone who lives on the Early Access store page). Survival is basically nonexistant. No enemies, broken game mechanics (many many basic menu options are unclickable), and quite glitchy even for my taste. This game will probably be ok in the end - it sets itself apart from Minecraft by having VERY different goals and game mechanics.

The good:
1. Sets itself apart from Minecraft in countless ways
2. Multiplayer servers are free to set up
3. Game is cheap-ish

The Bad:
1. Game is too glitchy and surivival is basically unplayable in current state
2. Graphics are worse than Minecraft (but not by much)
3. You can click blocks no matter how far away you are (hard to believe in reality, but ok)
4. You don't take fall damage? This is weird

I'd wait, or buy it cheap now and put it on ice for about 12 months.

How about 2 hours to be able to safely explore away from your base for more than 5 minutes at a time? And that's in what this game calls easy mode - Casual" mode it literally say is for people with jobs and families. (Who is the target audience

recommended: and perform below expectations. The game's basic generator can only function in the shallowest biomes (not enough oxygen deeper apparently)
hoursPlayed: and even then it will decline to near 0% efficiency before you reach the next layer. Said layer will freeze you to death in under a minute until you build a suit upgrade... using ore from the layer below it. Everything about the gameplay feels like it's punishing the player.\n\nApart from the mindbogglingly slow gameplay: The graphics are generally unappealing - it tries 'realistic' textures which don't look good in voxel games in my opinion

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFortresscraft is a fun game in the places it works, but there's a ton of emphasis on that, because there's a lot of places it simply doesn't. Because it was originally made for the Xbox, the controls on the PC feel terrible and stiff, and the frame rate is consistently below 6o fps. This could be just me due to not having a high processing power but while I had Skyrim on my PC, it was never as bad as how this game performs here. Building is slow and I feel like the UI is far too much of a struggle to put up with. Furthermore, this game is still in early access even though it's been in development for more than two years. What has hindered te development this long, I really can't imagine. I enjoyed what I could do when it worked, but I feel like compared  other titles of this genre *coughcough* Minecraft/Terraria *coughcough* Fortresscraft doesn't add up in end. Not every game can and should be like the rest, but it should at least live up to the standards set by it's competetitors, and unfortunately, FortressCraft Evolved really doesn't do that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played FortressCraft on the 360 quite a bit, enjoying the hunt for all those hidden little tools you could use to make playing the game more interesting. I especially enjoyed the idea of creating zed spawners. I must have created thousands of those things...

But anyway, on with THIS game.

I had to say this: it's not easy starting out. I had little time to read the help and starting tips before I realized that my suit energy was dropping fairly quickly. To top it off, I had to also wrestle with the controls before I was able to make my way to my crash site.

But once I managed to get the controls down, I was able to start mining for resources. I got lucky and found a tin and coal vein inside the mountain I set up camp on, and eventually found iron and copper (though they were a long climb down into the earth.

I think the suit energy idea is a good idea. It's going to keep you alive, and it allows you to stay out in the cold a while longer before you need to recharge. And the scanner idea was nice as well, though I think I know a tree when I see one. Unless it suddenly grows tentacles and tries to eat me. Then I'm just being eaten.

And the new entities in the the game have given me more questions than answers. There are these flying robots that, when I kill them, drop ruined stingers. Not sure what to do with those, or what they are suppose to do for the bots, but it's interesting. And let's not forget the wacky-looking spider thing I found stuck on the mountain. That thing wouldn't die, nor would it move. I'm curious as to how all of those things got there.

While this game is pretty fun to play, and the creative mode is a blast to mess with, I did have some general issues, ones that I'm sure some or most players will have run into.

1. Resource Management.
While I can understand that resources are going to be important for your survival, it just seems kind of ridiculous to have to travel hundreds of blocks away in order to find even basic resources (it took me over an hour to just find copper). And the majority of the time, my energy is being used to keep my few ore extractors going, or scanning for more areas to mine new resources. I've yet to find anything new.

2. Control Layout.
This is one of my biggest beefs, and for a good reason. As I said before, I had to fight with the controls for a minute before I could get moving, though it took me even longer to learn how to switch back to my scanner from my gathering tool. It also feel a little clunky, having to reach across the keyboard to hit a certain hotkey. I know the keys can be rebound, but I tend not to mess with that. Maybe a few minor rethinkings of the layout would be nice. Or controller support! I'm honestly one for full controller support, so maybe that could be a future addition.

3. Crafting.
The crafting system is relatively straight forward, which is nice, but requires resources that could take a lot of time to find, and even more time to gather. And even with the resources that are almost immediately found, the process requires more time and more resources. To illustrate my issue:

8 iron=1 iron bar, 15 iron bars=1 ore extractor.

It just seems a little tedious.

4. Environmetal Hazards.
Now, honestly, this is a cool feature, but one that needs some working. Heat keeps you from freezing to death, obviously. But what makes me a little irritated is the fact that you can't make heated rooms. It just seems like one of those things that you'd think would have been implemented a while back to help players better manage themselves. I'm really hoping it's added in a future update, though. Cold nights would be so much more pleasant.

5. Terrain.
This one is just something small, nothing major. But I feel like it's something that could be implemented at some point in even a minor update.
Having to jump to go up another block gets a little tedious, not to mention it's a little hard on the spacebar (at least mine, anyway). Maybe the option of automatically climbing up one block could make an appearance in a future update.

But other than that, this game is looking pretty good! I'm looking forward to seeing what the Devs have in store for futue updates, as well as what other players will suggest adding to it. This is a game that certainly has evolved from it's console predecessor, and it's done so pretty well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I have not played the Creative Mode.

Even in Early Access this is an incredible game.  You start off in the middle of no where freezing to death with only the energy in your suit and a couple of torches and ore extractors.  You immediately have to set off to find your crashed ship to try to salvage whatever you can to just survive the first night on this planet.  Once you're accustomed to surviving the night, you can start exploring all that FortressCraft has to offer.  Building automated bases, suit upgrades, crafting, etc.

The UI still needs to be cleaned up and more intuitive, but the devs are working on core functionality of the game first so expect a bit of a learning curve (if you have any questions the devs and other community members are always available on the forums),

New updates and features are being released all the time, multiplayer was just recently released (there's still a lot more work to do with multiplayer, but at least it's under way).  I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game with a good potential. However now, in it`s current state, it has two problems. First of all, it is vey, very buggy. Look at any part of the game and you will find bugs. Player falls through the floor, items cannot be moved to inventory, capacity of smelter changes randomly, sometimes items just disappear while dragging.
Second problem is balance. Prepare to wait a lot and to make many monotonous movements. Dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge. Then go to smelter and smelt for an hour. Capacity of smelter is low (and changes randomly) so you cannot just leave game and go for a walk.
Of course, there is automation in this game, everything can be automated. But you`ll spend hours and hours to craft automatic resource processing. And these hours will be very boring.
I dont recommend this game untill all bugs are fixed and long hours replaced with brief breaks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note:  This was always meant to be a temporary review.  I cannot find time to continually update this review as time goes on, though.  I will come back to the game someday just to check out the finished product.

Here are the pros:
1. Good graphics, the game is pretty in terms of lighting and bloom and so on, but it is a blocky style... though you should know that already.
2. Has a survival mode for game-like experience (not yet playable) and a creative mode for just building and chilling out.
3. The main menu looks kind of neat with all the sliding camera animations and dark techie rooms.
4. The way you enter worlds is cinematic and exciting the first time you play.
5. The worlds are huge.  I mean huge.
6. The game is a lot more affordable than most other commercial games in the genre.  (Minecraft was $25 last I checked.)

Cons:
1. Terrible UI/menu design/implementation, no mouse input!  what da hell.  That said, the game is in Early Access, and the devs admit the menu needs improvement.
2. Creative mode controls are awkward and simply not fun, feels very technical and poorly designed.
3. Many features do not seem to be working yet.  (Duh. Early Access.)  Some of these non-functional features are very hard to ignore.  For example, you cannot exit a map; you have to exit and reload the entire game to go to a different map.
4. Creative mode does not offer a survival mode toggle for testing the map.  (Or does it?)  I would have liked some level-editing capabilities for building survival mode levels with enemy placements and NPC dialogue scripting.
5. Achievements are bad.  An achievement for dying... riiiight. Perhaps the devs should refrain from adding achievements until the game is nearly complete?
6.  Multiplayer is not available at all and probably will not be available for a long time. (Clarification needed.)

Curious about the game's roadmap? Go here: http://www.fortresscraft.com/features/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Monotonous version of Minecraft with machines. I don't know the first version on X360 but Evolved, in this Alpha stage, isn't so appealing. Wait until Early Access ends.

Why i didn't like it so much:
1- Graphics is the real problem. Low framerate on Good preset (but it's good on Simple, so kind of OK). Models are horrible, especially block ones (like ore deposit boxes, ore extractors, ore refineries etc.). Also still buggy, time by time i see through blocks; can't see distant lands.
2- Survival mode? What is that? The only survival in-game is hypotermia which doesn't affect your gameplay. You only die and respawn. Ah, and your robot companion needs a power core. That's all.
3- GUI isn't so useful.
4- You have to identify every kind of block which i found it as a donkey work.
5- This game needs small amount of interactive guides imho. Only a small amount of them.

I'd like to make a more solid recommendation but it's unbearable in this state so wait, don't buy it now. This is my last Early Access title, i guess. I'm not a type of feedback guy, so, i shouldn't buy alpha and beta stage games. You shouldn't too, if you feel me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AT THE POINT OF WRITING THIS THE GAME IS IN EARLY ACCESS ~6/16/2015~

This game looks and seems like it could have a lot of potential but in the current state that it is in I cannot and will not recommend this game. There is pretty much little to no content that really keeps it worth while in the current state. I played 1.2 hours of this in survival mode and pretty much just gave up on it because, for one the content that is in survival mode is little to none other then just ore automation and two once you get it all up and running there is nothing to use your precious ores that you have collected and you just feel like you have wasted time. The upgrades in the game are all still in development so you cant really upgrade anything either so you don't really win at all.

One huge mistake is they went upon development backwards in my opinion! They started the game out as multiplayer and did single player as a add on when they should have focused upon single player which would provide more things to do. Without a good single player core how do you expect to have a good multiplayer? It doesn't really make sense at all to me at least... Which makes me kind of sad cause this game looks like it has a lot of potential but in the current form I really just cant say too much good about it.

Please Dev's don't give up on this game because of all the hate! Just keep working at it :) If the game gets to a more playable and enjoyable state I will change this review! What we need is more things to craft,upgrade, and just simply do more then building a red and blue house with our buddies. If we really wanted to do that we would get together and get out the old legos from our shelf!

So overall I wouldn't recommend buying this at the current state simply not enough content and things to do!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS:
- Nice graphic @ 60 FPS...
- awesome quick build...
- only spended 2,24€ on this game...

CONS:
- ...but really slow graphic build up
- ...with absolute no tutorial at all (if it's really only the 6 text boxes, when beginning the game, then make a better tutorial, like in Minecraft)
- ...but still want my money back, because the game doesn't work at all
- crashes continuous @ 60 FPS!!!
- the controller support is terrible, why not using the mapping of the X360 Indie Game version?
- the keyboard get's turned off every 5 minutes (runs perfect on windows)
- not working achievements (follow on Twitter, Run on 64 Bit version maximum settings, only two examples)
- absolute no music or ambient at all
- multiplayer games not really easy to set up
- crashes if I end the game

CONCLUSION:
I played this game allready on Xbox 360 before and it was a great game, but here in the PC version allmost nothing works. The controller support doesn't work, you can't configure your block set, can't switch tools and many other things too. The keyboard set up works so far, but often the keyboard get's disabled for some weird reasons. If I dig down, to get on lower levels, it get's stuck at 500 blocks lower level. The graphic doesn't build up anymore and the keyboard get's disabled. Please don't tell me, it's because my PC is too weak. The game runs allways at 60 FPS, so really no lag at all. Only the graphic doesn't build up. One of my biggest issue is, that there is no playable tutorial at all. It has so many new functions in comparisson with Minecraft, that a player can't know all that. To figure it out, would be probably a very long try and error. If the heavy bugs get solved and a short tutorial get's implemented, I give it another chance. Else I declare the game as dead. -.-'
I can live with not achieveable achievements, they're a nice add to games, but not necessary. ;)
But bad controls and tons of crashes are an absolute no go. :'( (\s/)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first read the game description I got quite excited as I thought of it as a Minecraft in a more futuristic environment. I've been playing for a few hours now and I find it rather frustrating. Mainly because some of the features just don't make sense and are not well explained and the worst of all: survival you're basically locked to just one world, it's NONSTOP snowy and windy and all you actually hear is the generator's humming and the wind blowing. So not only does the frustration add up, it's basically also very frustrating.

I made the mistake and got my brother a license as well as multiplayer was announced and again... was very disappointed as many features were not included and to date I have not managed to actually get a server running and even if I managed, it basically would only be a creative server. No thanks.

It doesn't help that the EarlyAccess information box targets a release towards the end of 2014. It's 2015 now and still far away from release. Worse: if you follow the dev's twitter (or twitch) account, you can actually follow him streaming other games. I think I stopped following him after he started playing the borderlands pre-sequel and even gloated about how much he played and streamed recently... at the time mostly borderlands. I wonder at what stage he actually tries to finish the game, rather than playing and streaming other games but his own. Obviously not much, otherwise the game probably would have been finished before the end of 2014 as promised. And I will not go into all the whining he does on Twitch and Twitter how bad money making is via steam and that he could do with a bit more games being sold etc...

So far, I cannot recommend this game at all if you're interested in the survival part. I cannot talk about the creative part, but then again - it says it's survival... and as that part is certainly by far not close to be finished or any good for that matter.

- world setup basically non-existant (other than free name choice)
- world setup features that are in with placeholders restrict to things like difficulty, and I think the amount of resources
- world setup cannot change the world you're landing on, or the weather, so you'll forever be stuck with annoying nonstop wind sounds... snow... cold... and wind... and snow... and wind... if you don't die of hypothermia, you'll either die real-life of boredom or the after-math of a depression
- it's nice that conveyor-belts etc. are being big announced in the screenschots but what's the point if it doesn't explain how the system works (and that's a big downer in general... many features have no explanation, i.e. research, what gives points, why would you scan things, what's the point... etc.) and for some of the resources I ran back and forth (very repetitive) for an hour and only had enough resources for one item, far away from any automatism... I wonder how some other players managed that.

Anyway, the game has been released December 10th in 2013. It's January 2015 and game is still in EarlyAccess.

That should answer if you really want to buy this game or not. If you don't believe me, feel free to follow his twitch and twitter accounts. I unfollowed the dev on all platforms shortly after his borderlands streaming, if I could, I would have requested my money back at that point.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMessy, garish and confusing. Amazing performance compared to that other block-based mining and crafting game, but spoiled by ugly over-the-top design. Visually, it's very confusing in Survival mode, with half your time spent in darkness and the other with snow in your face, not to mention that f***ing robot flying up into your face all the time, all of which makes me itch to hit Alt-F4. The keyboard interface is weak and unintuitive, eg. ESC button takes you to options menu instead of out of your current inventory or interface screen like every other game I've ever played. The engine has promise but just feels tasteless and tacky, would need a back-to-basics overhaul in the design and styling to make it enjoyable to spend any time on, and development seems slow. I worry that this is yet another nail in the coffin for Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cons:

This game randomly hard-locks my computer. This happens with no other program and I have throughly tested my memory.

The menu does not pause the game, so you can die from adjusting settings (especially in the first 5 hours in a world).

You're in constant peril of death for the first several hours of the game and after patiently strategeicly attempting for almost 12 gameplay hours in a world, I just got to the point of crafting the first 2nd tier item. Survival is frustratingly slow.
You start with a single device to smelt ores, and to build another is a 3rd teir build and reportedly among the community takes roughly 30 hours of gameplay to get to. I have more than 20 hours and can still not yet survive going deep enough to *find* T3 resources.

Can very easily jump into a block and see through the level. There is even a four-click method to see through the world reliably at any time you want. Major game breaker.


Pros:

The mining is automated for the most part as you grow. Then the smelting becomes automated. Then the building.
Cool system, allows for huge top-end growth.

Really nice voxel graphics.


Summary:

The ore mining/energy/processing is a really cool idea, but this game has screwball glitches, partial graphics failures regularly, inventory failures often, and total system lockups on a healthy computer. Lets be honest, this is a minecraft clone, and not worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have mixed feelings about FortressCraft. Granted it is still in development so I'm going to forgive a lot of things, but anyhow.
This is by all accounts a MineCraft copycat with a few extra features. The graphics aren't nearly as pixelated as minecraft but most of the blocks 'glisten'. though one good feature is the fact that I can copy and paste structures to quickly create buildings and landscapes and the number of block types is also really nice. controls are a bit unresponsive and result in a lot of misplaced blocks. there is also a seemingly infinite range for placing/removing blocks which, while at sometimes is really nice, is actually quite frustrating when you accidentally delete a block on the otherside of your building and have to trudge all the way over there to place it again. FortressCraft Evolved has a lot of potential to be better than MineCraft but at the moment I recomend sticking with MineCraft.

reviewText:
Can you escape an infinite, inhospitable alien planet?

Spoler alert!  No, you cannot.  The game is incomplete.

This game will seduce you with a bunch of false promises and then break your heart with placeholder content, missing artwork and prose, obsolete branches of the tech tree, and unimplemented features.

I'd like to say that in a couple of years this will be a great game, but the solo developer has his ego tangled up in this project and doesn't seem to have the perspective or artistic integrity to see the problems with this game.

reviewText:
This little gem caught my eye about a year ago, when it was in early access. I decided back then to let it mature before buying it. As such I was excited to see it was out of early access and the full release was out.

As another voxel based survival game this one seperates itself from the pack by focusing more or automation and refinement, matched really only by Factorio (but in 3D!!!). It looks great, at first glance, until I bought the game and played it...

It played smooth. REAL smooth, in that it was between 150 and 200 FPS. There is an option in the Settings menu to change that, but it didn't do anything. No change whatsoever. So you try restarting the game, and there is still no difference. Now that is a pretty basic thing to set up, so why it doesn't function is beyond me (again, in a full title out of early access). It hogged all my computers resources to keep up with that rediculous update speed. But ow well, let's play on!

So you start in a tutorial setting, protected from outside influences by a forcefield, which lifts when the tutorial is done. Awesome! The tutorial is short but informative, so even after restarting hundreds of games I can't see much of a speedbump there, and it's practical...Until the shield lifts and a giant spider robot walks over your base, its feet several blocks away from its legs (assuming said legs aren't jerking over it's head).

At this point I noticed the text at the bottom right of the screen saying Development Build...Okay, probably started a Beta through Steam???...uhm...no...the game is still in beta...and the spider is supposed to be some kind of boss enemy to be encountered later in the game, which was left at the players spawn probably to debug / test.

Why do I have a Development Build for a game that has been out for 5 / 6 months and without running a Beta?

This game is not done, and it is out of early access. I concider that seriously disrespectfull towards the customer and a violation of my consumer rights. I don't mind buying a product that isn't finished, as long as you're honest about that and don't play morally and legally questionable games.

In 10 years of Steam patronage I have never ask for a refund, and to be honest I thought Age Of Survival warranted it, but at least they are honest about the game not being done yet...

EDIT: People don't seem to understand, so to make a bit more clear: I liked this game, I really did, but there is no excuse for selling a game that isn't finished, that is still a 'Developer Build'. The moment we as consumers accept that as 'okay' we collectively accept blatant disregard for our consumer rights and those rights will disappear.

Steam has agreed with my complaint by refunding my payment, so at least I know I'm not entirely wrong by fighting this...

Short version:
FortressCraft is basically a Minecraft + tech mod clone, minus Minecraft's charm. With a side of difficuilt and awkward to use interface. Plus an extra helping of bugs (even for early access). Not recommended.

Longer version:
On startup Fortresscraft greets you with possibly the most detailed and intricate menu ever. This turned out to be a bad omen though as it's also possibly the most difficuilt to use menu ever. Difficuilt to the point of needing a tutorial to navigate. However after much random mouse button mashing I managed to overcome this hurdle and start a new survival world. Alas, I was one of the lucky few. We should spare a moment of thought for all those poor souls who failed to navigate the main menu, and instead flocked to Steam's forum for a solution... on how to use the main menu.

Once the world had loaded and the ringing in my ears caused by the really LOUD crashing ship passed I came to another hurdle, the help screen. I quickly browsed over the help text and tried taking in as many hotkeys as I could. There are a number of them as the only way to select a tool is with a hotkey. Which you can't rebind.

After skimming the help screen I tried to close it by pressing escape, nothing. Tried clicking on stuff, nothing. Only after rolling my face across the keyboard, not once, but twice! Was I finally rid of the cursed help screen. (edit: The escape key sort of works in the latest version)

With arch-villan help screen defeated I was finally able to take in the world, the very bland world. This is where the clone shows through. Even the block's textures have that familiar MInecraft look, albeit high resolution. All other voxel games have moved away from cubes into their own form of voxels, and all of those new voxel games feel nice and fresh.  So coming back to a cube game can feel a bit underwhelming. Made worse by a world that has nothing going on. It's just snow and the occassional tree. Totally lacking in features that convince you this is an alien world.

The actual game, in it's current state, is centered around building an automated mining network similar to many Minecraft tech mods where you have mining machines that feed a conveyor of some sort. You then need a power network to run those machines etc.  So far the stuff in game is similar to stuff I've seen in mods. Which isn't a bad thing. Expanding on these ideas could lead to somewhere interesting. But.

And it's a big but. This game has a lot strange design features that either take away player agency or are there to ♥♥♥♥ you off. Like the decision to go against the convention of every other game in this genre, and reverse the block breaking and block placing mouse buttons. Those buttons are so ingrained now that I'm constantly wrecking my machines or digging holes when I meant to place a machine, infuriating. Then there is the bizarre inventory mechanic where you can't choose what you put into a machine. The game decides for you and it's pretty much always the wrong choice. So you have to wait around for the machine to finish then hope it chooses the correct material next go around.

Finally the inventory or lack of. The inventory is just for show it lets you know how much of each block you are carrying and that's it. Since it's non-interactive you can't organise it or anything you can usually do with an inventory. The only thing it lets you do is spew blocks everywhere via another hotkey. A number of those blocks will often get lost because of physics bugs. Spewing is the only way to get stuff from your inventory into a storage container. The problem being another container in the vicinity will suck up your block spew. Meaning you need to empty that container then try again. As you imagine can this becomes a real chore, real quick.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a joke. Bought this game for $3 and deeply regret my purchase.

The movement and mouse acceleration make this game unplayable. Ordinary things like mining, block placement, construction seem very hard to execute. Building a house is such a frustrating thing that makes you rage quit.

Also the distance view algorithm is a weird one. As the world spawns around you, its made in this weird animation thingy that looks like blocks falling from the sky. At first I didn't know what it is, it seemed like a glitch or something. Anyway the problem is that this paralax effect induces nausea for people with motion sickness. After 30 minutes or playtime I felt so sick that I had to stop playing and have no incentive to play this ever again.

The Ideea seems good but the execution is terrible. I do not recomend this game.

My rating: 2/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I write this Review because of the especially bad reactions of the developers, the game itself has possibilities (after many improvements).
I suspect that the developers really do not know who their customers are and this is actually very important thing in gaming, you depends on them. I see this because of some of your responses towards negative reactions and to normal questions, many of these reactions are quite bluntly and in most cases when you get a reaction like that in a store you walk to the next store.

And who are your clients ?? ..... I a gamer and beside me hundreds of other gamers. We have not always right but we do have when it comes to our game experiences. Besides, we are not your enemy but an ally (as gamers we want to help you), but we take care of our own brothers (fellow gamers) protects for mistakes we have experiance our selfs.

Last week began Fortress Craft Evolved again, because i got new information and I went deeper into the game. Because when I bought the game a year ago, the game was a disappointed for me and I marked it as not playable - Creative mode was boring for me and i didenn't have a goal and i didden't know there was a survival mode back then.

Now I'm starting over again (I discovered the survival mode) and I try to find some reading matirial on the game, but there where nearly none (there are a number YourTubers). Unfortunately, that is because there is no community behind the game.

How come there is no community? Then I come back to my beginning, by the failt of communication from you as developers, what result is that gamers have no connection with the game and walk away. Why should I as a gamer take part of a community when the developer think they are better than me?

I also know quite annoing to read bad things of your game, it's your baby, I also know that a bad reaction can hit hard and that the first reaction is to hit hard back in respond to it, but usually that is wrong. I would recommend writing a response, wait a day, after reading your responce like you  get the as customer get the response, throw your reaction away and write a respones you as your customer would like to get. It is all about your customers not about you as a developer/person. Every reaction you get is not an attack on you (exept this one), every reaction is there to make your baby better.

Give customers love you and they give love back but give them hate you get hate back.


I also promise to them when I notice that you as developers improve your behavior, my opinion (like many others) wil chance to the better. Because we as gamers want the best game as posable game and a few even better developers, but like the game you are not at your full potential and i feel i have to call you on your bad habbits.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lacks polish on every corner unfortunately. Yes this is an early access title and yes EA can have bugs. That's not what i'm talking about.

The overall concept of the game is great.

The balancing and core ideas of the game are great too. It's very clever above all how the progression in survival works and forces you to preserve materials on every corner even after a couple of hours.

But just about every core feature that's in the game feels irky / buggy to work with:

The bad

- Right click accidentally with your building gun on any machine and it will deconstruct Losing ressources that were in it and generally being a nuisance.

- The whole interface is very problematic, disappearing cursor, unintuitive controls, buttons that dont work as they should. Nothing gamebreaking, you eventually learn how to work around them. Inconsistent use overall. (Some things require e" to charge them
date: some need to be opened first for instance...) Annoying nevertheless.\n\n- The Energy and Transport system are cool but very annoying to work with. Moving a line one block lower because you misjudged something and built it a bit off
hoursPlayed:
will cost you a ♥♥♥♥♥on of ressources and a blob of interconnecting logisticshoppers.

- Energytransfer. We have lasers that transfer power over 64 blocks but no cables that distribute power to something 2 blocks away. Instead you have to kinda misuse batteries to connect things. I suspect it's because of the 1 block 1thing development philosophy that this game went for. In the early days of Industrialcraft over at Minecraft they used cables that measured 1 x 1meter... not a perfect solution but at least you had something to work with. If there is anything in the techtree then it's way to far down. (Solar panels before basic cables ? Really ?)

- The energy grid is very simplistic and lacks complexity once you see through it. It's just batteries / machines that have energy
voteText: or they dont now distribute evenly with limited tools.\n\n- Combat... should have left it out
helpfulPercent: it just looks really bad and unfinished and doesnt add anything to the game.\n\n- Once you have a bigger base you need some sort of navigating tools so you can dig straight tunnels to where you need them because the game is seriously annoying if you have to build 2-3 blocks to connect things. The game has a holomap for that and a map that is very confusing to use and needs alot of time to get used to. Simple coordinates on the scanner would have solved this problem entirely
votesHelpful: but no
votesTotal:
we have a bloated graphics effect.

- Death doesnt mean anything. It just ports you back with ALL ressources. Take the survival aspect out of it if death is meaningless.

- Unnecessary robots flying around in your face
votesFunny: and the spiderbot. Have fun with the spiderbot
commentsCount:
it doesnt do anything except block your view in your base day in and day out.

- The Scanner doesnt work proper. While the scanner is cool if you scroll the mousewheel once up or down you see that the thing is buggy. Pretty much sums up how such an easy spottable bug got past the Dev or that he didn't care about it.

- Graphics are somewhat dated. Not a huge thing.

- The name... has nothing to do with fortresses
column16:
should have named it Factorycraft or something.

- Multiplayer is very buggy. The dev is not capable of reproducing alot of the reported issues. We could reproduce them on every single client in the first try. Well... yeah.



Whats cool:

- Ore distribution is really cool and works better than in minecraft as it forces you to branch out the base naturally and think of ways to make things easier.

- The Scanner is cool.

- Energysystem of your suit forces you to be carefull about your ressources.

- Progression is really smart and fun. You can't just step away 10 hours and then have a ♥♥♥♥♥on of ressources
column17:
the limited automated storages make sure of that.



All in all

I get the feeling that whoever programmed this is potentially a great game designer but shouldn't be the person who pushes out any releases. Have someone that does quality control and treat this as a conceptual prototype. The game lacks an overall control / ui concept and now wants to leave Early Access."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most games start off easy and get progressively harder in order to balance out the players advancement and remain interesting. This game does the exact opposite. Maybe not in terms of skill, but in patience. The first few hours (if not more) of gameplay are incredibly slow. There is a general sense of just not getting anywhere.

And when you do manage to get a decent industry up and running and you actually have the resources to get things done, you realize there was no point. At this point in the game's developement, the only thing you can do with the resources you gather (Id guess there are fewer than 10 useful ones) is making machines that automate...gathering more resources...

With such limiting gameplay and more bugs than a rainforest floor, its difficult to imagine it leaving early access in the near future

reviewText:
I'm not too happy about this one... The graphics are indeed quite good, and there are some improvements over minecraft (Yes, I am comparing this game to MC + Tech mods) including the jetpack, the flashlight and large ore veins.
But there's also a bunch of problems which might be because this game left EA too early.

Let's talk about progress. I normally play survival in MC, but in this game I got bored by it. Actually bored, not the casual play-something-else bored. If I want to progress, I need to produce a lot of bars, which means a lot of ore miners and even more power to power my equipment. If I do that I'll attract the attention of mobs. I could run my mining operations at a slower speed, but where's the fun in that? To make matters worse, the base income in ore, metals and power is so low that you REALLY need a lot of everything, for which you need a lot of resources. And you don't have those.

ARTHER, that tiny flying thing by your side. I guess having it give you energy is neat, but I don't get how a tiny flying robot has better power cells and solar panels than you do in your space suit. In addition it's supposed to display vital information to you. But you can't really read that if it points away from you, or is sitting inside a wall.

Threat level, while a good idea, is simply not working out. In the very beginning of the game you are not getting attacked because you're not mining/smelting enough to attract any mobs. But once your base evolves, you'll suddenly get multiple waves of wasps every 10 or so minutes. And your turrets don't target mobs immediately, so you need a lot of them.

Wasps are the main enemy (before the heavies and bosses appear). But they are only a way to make your base receive damage, they aren't fun to defend against at all. If you build a wall around your base they fly through it, if you shield your CPH they shoot through the wall, they can turn invisible and invincible, etc.
Fortunately there's that big spider robot which is supposed to defend you. Unfortunately it doesn't. When a wave begins it starts walking away and doesn't defend the base. I guess that it is actually heading towards the wasp's spawn location, but I'm not convinced that it does anything once it's there.

Finally, the CPH. It is just an excuse to slow you down. In the beginning you may depend on it, but later on it is just useless. It is called Central Power Hub for no reason, it's like a PTG at 30% efficiency and you can't feed power into it from your power plant. It is the one and only target for wasps, yet it doesn't have any means of defending itself. It fires a beam upward in which you can't build at all, despite having no effect whatsoever (no it's a bad beacon). The worst part is that you can't even move it. Spawned on a hill? Too bad.

This game would have been very good if you didn't had to constantly defend against wasps.
Oh wait... I can change that :)[imgur.com]
I had to stop playing or I would have wasted countless hours modifying the game and still not have the fun I was hoping to get through it... progress is still too slow.

reviewText:
Don't let the high recommendation fool you. This game is awful. It's completely unfinished, it may as well not even have a tutorial for all the good the tutorial does you, and is barely functional in all other respects. Even if it were functional it is completely devoid of personality or spirit. What started as a clone of Minecraft hasn't evolved into anything worthwhile. Skip this one.
Edit: The developer commented, so i figured I'd give a bit more detailed reasoning as to why I returned this game.
a) the game runs like ♥♥♥ on a current gen ASUS,
b) the first game I played I spent 20 minutes debugging why the power hub and conveyer setup wasn't working (the hub spawned a block too high), and had to restart
c) you've published the game with the developer console active
d) the robot tries to fly into the optimal place to display its message(which was clipped by the edge of the screen for me), and it took me several minutes of chasing him down before I realized that's what was going on,
e) there's a general lack of visual communication when you look at objects to try to figure out what they do,
f) things that, I assume, were working normally, looked buggy and unpolished, like the intro screen and the level generation screen
g) the visuals and audio, while hardly placeholder, desperately need a polish pass (the lighting and shaders especially)
h) you can die in the starting zone simply by not learning the game fast enough.
All in all, a horrific first impression. All the in-game help menus in the world can't make up for a bad impression.

reviewText: Fortresscraft: Evolved is... awkward.\nAlright... where to start? Well, I suppose I should start off by saying I can tell this game takes inspiration from industrial"-themed Minecraft mods
date: in that you're setting up production chains and transporting items and mining and all that stuff. The problem is it's only taken inspiration
recommended:
and pretty much fails in every other regard.

The good:
Fortresscraft is initially simple and you might have fun for the first hour
hoursPlayed: but the fun soon stops as the game becomes a parade of annoyances
voteText: either due to bad game design
helpfulPercent: intentional grinding
votesHelpful:
and a slew of other bullcrap that keeps you from that carrot on a stick; progression.

The bad:
Now
votesTotal: you may be wondering
votesFunny: "Higgs
commentsCount: what's so annoying and bad about the game? Look at all the positive reviews!" To that I say; everyone is stupid except me
column16: and you... if you listen to my gripes about this game.\n\nStarting off
column17: the graphics. Now
column18: I might be playing this on an ancient GTX630 graphics card
column19: but that's still no excuse for a game with these sorts of graphics to not be hitting 60FPS
column20: at the very least on low settings. The models are simple and bland
column21: they look like they're out of a PS2 game (a bargain-bin one at that)
column22: and the blocky terrain clashes with this. The textures are muddy
column23: dull and needlessly high-res
column24: and have parallax for the most mundane things. The developer seems to have slapped on as many special rendering effects on top of the game to cover up the mediocrity of the art style
column25: to the point that it can be difficult to see when some of the bloom effects or screen overlays do their best to blind you. As a result
column26: the game tends to chug despite the low poly-count.\n\nThe gameplay itself is
column28: what you'd expect from a Minecraft ripoff. Break and place blocks. Simple enough
column29: if the UIs weren't a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nightmare to navigate. Every single screen seems to run on a different set of rules
column30: and despite what might seem like a solid framerate your clicking and dragging will be laggy as hell. The focus of the game
column32: are obnoxiously unexplained; even with the in-game help it either seemed to gloss over the function or rules of things lioke hoppers
column33: which never EVER behaved in the way you wanted them to. I'd be fine with that if I could mine by hand
column34: but you CAN'T. Ore blocks aren't supposed to be broken apparently
column35: and yield junk when you turn your laser onto them. You have to place a grinder thing beside an ore vein
column36: then wait for it to chew through it sluggishly. It's obnoxious and it just doesn't make sense. Even breaking normal blocks manages to be awkward and clunky
column37: they break far too fast and the range for the laser is too far
column38: making digging stairwells a chore when you accidentally dig at more or less than a 45* angle
column39: meaning you have to dig out the ceiling or place blocks to make the stairs smooth again. With the way blocks break in Minecraft
column40: you have far better control over what you're digging
column41: to the point that I find mining to actually be one of the more enjoyable activities even after at least 5 years of playing the game
column42: Fortresscraft's awkwardness just vomits all over that sense of zen that I get.\n\nIt's worth mentioning again that almost nothing is actually given context in the game. Despite dismantling a tree with my laser I can't make planks to make a crate to store all this garbage in my inventory. What do all these over-detailed glowing plants do? Slimes everywehere? Are they bad guys? Sometimes when I'm underground a block decides it hates me and kills me (dying has no consequences outside of respawning
column43: yet another annoyance). Are THOSE bad guys? How do I fight them? I had to go down to -150 meters to find lithium ore
column44: yet the device that beams power underground requires that I already have piles of lithium? Why do I have to nrun back and forth between my power station because there's little option for providing power to underground drills? How many times am I going to get HYPOTHERMIA?\n\nAlso
column45: no pickaxes in the game apart from the logo. That really miffs me for some reason
column46: maybe because I can't mine myself and the machines are frustrating to deal with. Placing conveyor belts is an exasperating chore; they never go the way you want them to the first time
column47: and you'll often need to dig a hole to stand in to get at the right angle to place them up a wall (that doesn't even make SENSE).\n\nThe ugly
column49: UGLY:\nDid I mention this game is ugly? Holy hell is it ugly. Again
column50: I have to reitterate that the flat
column51: blocky terrain clashes with the semi-detailed models; Minecraft might be ugly too but at least it's a consistent sort of ugly. Every texture is far more detailed than it needs to be
column52: to the point that it looks less like a texture and more like a grey blob at every distance apart from directly in front of your eyes
column53: in which case it's got so much detail it looks almost uncanny valley in a way. The lighting SUCKS
column54: it hurts my eyes. I hate looking at this game.\n\nIn conclusion
column56: absolutely must play a voxel-based mining game with machines
column57: buy Minecraft and install Technic launcher
column58: there's dozens of well-made and POLISHED mods for you to play
column59: with far more content and without the graphics drain and constant frustrations."

reviewText:
I loved fortress craft at first up until the last changes.  Try and argue with the developer is like arguing with a brick wall.

Problem 1: Play style and lvl a simple difcuality level is needed.
Peaceful - Those who just want to do the manufacturing part of the game and make stuff.
Easy - Some monster shows up on rarity.  Start setting up defences etc form here.
Medium - Diffcualtiy as normal
Hard - Go for it and make it a little tougher enemy etc.
Hard Core - If you die, you game is erase but your highest stats will be listed.


Problem 2 - Generators does not work below 300.  I really don't care but like to generators to work at all levels.

Problem 3 - You spend more time mining and collecting resources then building an actual base.  Its already complicated as it is.  You don't need to add more problems on top of problems.

Problem 4 - changes are soo annoying that when they do changes it makes the game worst then what it is.
- Examples
- Generators don't work below 300.  I have an entire system setup for that and now I have to go back and fix it.  I barely have enough materials to make a power laser to get that far down let alone finding a way back down.
- Monsters spawns soo much that all your ore is gone before you get it up.  Plus going back to make all those changes is a pain.  Even Minecraft changes is better then this.
- Force to use high speed tubes vs oonveyors,  It means hours of replacement again mining speed of the ore is slow going even after upgrades.
- 8-1 ore - yea millions of ore and on turns into 20 k or so.  With so much needed to build, who needs ore monsters.

In addition, read the forms and you can see all the crappy changes they keep making.  Yea, its there game; but, who is paying for it???  Us of course.

reviewText: I don't know whether I liked this game or not.  This is the first game like this that I ever played.  I never played Minecraft or Factorio, and my one attempt at Terraria left me lost and confused.  So I simply found this game too difficult, as it appears to assume knowledge on my part that I simply don't have.  I had no issues with the game as far as bugs or whatever: for what it is the game seems to be working as intended and doing what it's doing.  I don't know whether to recommend this or not, as it was simply beyond me.    I suppose if you like 'simulations' instead of games you might like this; it appears to accurately simulate (without Fitz/Simmons) how to not survive on an alien world.  Maybe it's fun; I just don't know.

reviewText:
If this was an Early Access game, I would be gobsmacked. However as a full release, there are some glaring flaws I noticed in just the first hour.

Foremost, the tutorial for a game this complicated should continue through the first five hours, lightly stepping in whenever the player encounters a new mechanic to explain it. I spent over an hour in this game trying to do one thing, and one thing only. I wanted to automate power transmission from the main generator to the coal mining drill, and subsequently automate coal transmission from the drill to the generator that burns it. In over an hour, I came no closer to figuring this out than I did watching the video at the top of the page.

Secondly, the crafting system interface needs to be scrapped and redone. Impossible to find crafting requirements without more than a minute of searching through menus and lists, meanwhile 60 percent of the screen is taken up by ridiculous sci-fi" window borders that do LITERALLY NOTHING AT ALL. If you are going to copy minecraft
date: at least copy the parts that were user friendly.\n\nThirdly
recommended: do you know why blocks take a few seconds to break in minecraft
hoursPlayed:
but appear instantaneously when building? ITS BECAUSE IT WARNS YOU WHEN YOU HAVE ACCIDENTALLY DONE THE WRONG ACTION. I spent more time than I can measure switching from the thing I actually WANTED to build back to BLOCKS OF DIRT just to fill in A HOLE I DIDNT MEAN TO DIG. This is utterly ridiculous.

HOWEVER

The concept has incredible potential. Adding automation and base defense to a minecraft style operation creates both drama and empowerment
voteText: and it would be something I REALLY want to enjoy
helpfulPercent: but these initial issues with the OBSCENE learning curve
votesHelpful: clunky interface
votesTotal: and other oversights overshadow a very good idea. Fix these issues and the game will improve.\n\n2/5"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is pretty bad. I gave it a shot before and after major updates, and it's just depressingly bad. As soon as I made it through the clunky tutorial, the first thing I see is some random giant robot near spawn with it's limbs freaking out. When I went to investigate, I noticed the feet" wear moving along the ground with the limbs flying in every direction. There was also no collision box with the entity... Anyways
date: I just felt like in both cases this game repelled me from any desire to really advance in the tech and get immersed.\n\nIt's also worth noting the lacking visual impact of the intro cinematic. You'd think an exploding space station would be interesting

reviewText:
Good luck scouring forums for any sort of help at all. I advise to steer clear of the developer because he will just be sarcastic and rude with all his advice and assume you have been watching his twitch for months on end and that you have to know by now what each research unlocks and how to build some of the more complex setups that he cant be bothered to write in the help menu inside the game. after a few months i returned to the game saw some updates and progress and started a new world only to find much of the research had been jumbled up a bit. not a huge issue but when i had asked the dev where certain things were he just said its in the help menu" well the item was in the help menu but all it told me is what is crafted with the item not how to craft it or unlock it in research... he swore up and down that it wasnt in the lab and that it was researched early on ingame. it was in fact in the lab and using the lab is a hit or miss on getting what you want unless you search the forums....

searching forums would be great and dandy but the information is not always current like i said he moves things around changes where they go which means an old topic could tell you to research something entirely different and researching in the lab isnt an easy thing that takes a little power and a few moments.

-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-

until the ingame help menus actually give helpful information i cant reccomend anyone buy this game and put up with this cranky developer. its still a fun and interesting game and i will continue to play but i cant advise anyone to pay full price for this game. pick it up on sale or spend your money on a better game
date: also the early rush from EA was a bad move and its really not ready to be sold as a full complete game."
